componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Denise, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Rowan Companies Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
Chris Pitre, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Rowan's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call, and thank you for your interest in Rowan. A copy of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found our website at rowan.com.Jo
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Rowan's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call, and thank you for your interest in Rowan. A copy of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found our website at rowan.com.
Joining me on the call this morning are Tom Burke, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Keller, Executive Vice President, Business Development; and Stephen Butz, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to remind you that expectations expressed during this conference call are forward-looking statements and are subject to risks and uncertainties, such as market conditions, commodity prices, offshore drilling activity levels and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our earnings release and SEC filings on our website, which more fully describe forward-looking statements and risk factors and other events that could impact future results.
Please note that information contained herein is as of the date of today's call and may be outdated at the time of any replay of this call.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom Burke, Rowan's President and Chief Executive Officer. Tom?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Good morning, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter and Full-year 2016 Earnings Call. We appreciate your participation today and your continue to interest and investment in Rowan. Following my prepared comments, Mark will give you an update
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. Good morning, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter and Full-year 2016 Earnings Call. We appreciate your participation today and your continue to interest and investment in Rowan. Following my prepared comments, Mark will give you an update on the offshore drilling market. And then, Stephen will walk you through our financial performance and guidance. After that, we will open the call up for questions.
In the fourth quarter 2016, we announced several key transactions that solidified our long-term growth and financial stability, even though [indiscernible] earnings continue to be pressured by challenging market conditions. Our announcements of a joint venture with Saudi Aramco, our successful bond offering and [indiscernible] execution of our fleet strategy through continuous sales of our older assets and our outstanding operational and safety performance made the quarter remarkable on many fronts. We accomplished these milestones while continuing to effectively reduce our cost and improve our focus on efficiency across the company. These transactions and solid operational execution mean there are visible liquidity runway now extends comfortably into the next decade, allowing us more flexibility to invest in attractive growth opportunities.
Stephen will review our financial performance in detail, so I will only make a few comments. We reported a loss of $0.19 per share in the fourth quarter, down from $0.04 of earnings per share in the previous quarter. The results this quarter were impacted by a $33.6 million loss in our proactive early retirement of debt. Excluding this loss, our $0.08 of earnings per share this quarter beat consensus. 
Our fourth quarter EBITDA was $143 million versus consensus estimate of $132 million, mainly driven by solid cost control and higher revenue efficiencies.
During the quarter, we executed 2 debt capital market transactions. While we would have preferred to extinguish debt at a discount, we are certainly pleased by the market's recognition of our solid financial position effectively, identifying us as a company that will confidently move through the remainder of this downcycle and emerge in a condition of strength.
I'm pleased that Rowan has led the peer group in relative TSR over [ph] the last 3-year period. And in 2016, we generated [indiscernible] return of 12%. Our strong operational performance in 2016, aided by our outstanding operational uptime of over 98% helped drive solid cash generation. Of course, this uptime performance wouldn't be meaningful if weren't accompanied by our best safety performance on record. 
For a company to have accomplished these performance measures during another year of intense focus on cost reductions is truly a well-founded source of pride for the men and women who work at Rowan. 
However, just as important during this downturn, is that we are highly focused for making structural changes to how we operate to ensure this outstanding performance becomes repeatable and sustained.
During the fourth quarter, we sold 2 of our remaining older assets, the Gorilla II and Gorilla III. This followed the sale of 3 other older assets in 2015. 4 of the 5 sold rigs are now restricted to non-drilling activities. We have only 2 older stack rigs left, allowing us to more fully concentrate our support on rigs mix that will have a meaningful contribution to our earnings when the market recovers.
We're thrilled with our recently announced partnership with Saudi Aramco who has been our largest customer for over 10 years and we're delighted to further that relationship. The new company will expand its fleet over time which will help Saudi Aramco accomplish its strategic goals as well as provide a source to stability and unparalleled growth to Rowan, truly a win-win.
Stephen will provide more details in a moment on this important long-term value creation opportunity. 
Now I would like to share with you thoughts on the market.
A year ago, the year the market was bleak as we expected further decline in demand for both Jack-up and Deepwater market. That forecast proved to be true. We've seen operated budgets decline for 3 years in a row, assisted by lower rig day rates and other costs. As we've seen in cycles in the past, activities with lower capital commitment, batches unconventional land drilling and shallow water Brownfield projects recover more quickly than larger capital-intensive activity such as ultradeep water exploration and development. We saw some improvements in oil prices last quarter and OPEC production cuts further supported crude oil prices. This stability, in all, seems to be driving increased tendering activities for late 2017, especially for Jack-ups. However, the floating market seems to be pushing off to 2018. 
While becoming more comfortable with forecasting and reasonable recovery over the coming years, more attrition of older asset is necessary for true recovery. We have seen further Jack-up and floaters scrapping and requirements recently and expect those to continue over the next years. While a robust recovery of the drilling market may take multiple years, we are confident that the strength of our balance sheet and our operational performance will carry us through.
Finally, as with previous quarters, we continue to have a keen focus on optimal capital allocation with impressive work that our finance team has done in extending our visible runway combined with our extremely solid operational performance in a market recovery, that is becoming a little [indiscernible] each day, we feel well-positioned to act on many attractive opportunities that come our way. Those opportunities may take many forms from debt requirements too stressed asset acquisitions, but we'll always view them through the same long-term shareholder value lens.
Now, for look at the market where Rowan competes, I'll hand the call over to Mark.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. As we enter 2017, we reflect on our position in the cycle and look forward cautiously optimistic that this year will present a turning point for the industry though recovery may be modest for several years. This mo
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. As we enter 2017, we reflect on our position in the cycle and look forward cautiously optimistic that this year will present a turning point for the industry though recovery may be modest for several years. This morning I will visit with you about the Jack-up and ultra-Deepwater markets and our outlook for the year and conclude with a few thoughts on the attrition needs that our industry must address.
We were pleased to report several jack-up contract extensions on our last fleet status update. The additional projects signed in Trinidad exhibit our customer satisfaction and our outstanding drilling performance and our continued commitment to have Rowan as their chosen partner in executing their drilling programs. Although we did not disclose the day rates due to the competitive nature of the global markets, they continue to provide significant operating margin, and we were happy to add utilization to those 3 rig units. 
In the North Sea, we currently have 3 Jack-ups contracted and 3 available. We're in discussions with multiple operators about opportunities for the Rowan Norway, the Rowan Stavanger and the Rowan 6 with project commencements seem weighted toward the second half of 2017. We're looking at P&A work, both in Norway and the U.K. sector but also considering attractive opportunities outside of the region.
We continue to see the most promising opportunity for increased demand in the Middle East. We're honored to be selected as the 50-50 joint venture partner with Saudi Aramco and expect that this new company will gain significant market share within Saudi Aramco's fleet of jack-ups in the coming years. We look forward to the commencement of the company in the second quarter. 
Throughout the region, we see a focus on high specification Jack-ups and our 2 available units, EXL I and EXL IV are being tendered aggressively both in the Middle East and around the world.
The Gorilla IV and EXL III continue operations with the offshore and the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. We see several additional opportunities in the region as operators look to develop lower-cost, faster-cycle Brownfield projects in the current budget environment.
quickly touch on other areas of the world, we see increased tender activity in Southeast Asia. However, we anticipate initial needs will be met by units currently in the region. We are actively participating in contracting opportunities in West Africa as operators look to high-grade units in that market. In Mexico, we're closely monitoring the bidding rounds and expect multiple shallow water blocks to be offered in 2017. However, the commencement of these projects may not materialize until some time in 2018.
Worldwide marketing jack-up utilization is now 68%, but we anticipate the bottoming of the trough within 2017 for Jack-ups. While downward pressure on day rates may continue due to idle supply and the newbuilds waiting to enter the market, the combination of an increase in joint activity and in anticipation of continued attrition should improve effective utilization levels worldwide, especially in niche markets.
Now let's look at the ultra-deepwater market. Market utilization fell approximately 9% during 2016, and we expect 2017 to be another challenging year as new contract awards struggle to keep pace with contract loss.
As operators, seem focus on capital spending in short cycle investments, several ultra- Deepwater projects that we previously anticipated commencing in 2017 now appear to be slipping into 2018. However, we are pleased with ongoing conversations with our customers about opportunities for available drillships and continue to believe that dual BOP, 1,250-ton units will be the first to return to work. These rigs offer operators the technical capabilities that give them the flexibility to address their worldwide portfolios that are especially critical to the demand in drilling and regulatory requirements in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. 
Two of our 4 units are currently contracted in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico and our remaining 2 units are warm stacked. We believe that warm stacking is the best approach for these vessels as our customers have made it clear that cold stacking will be the last in line to be contracted.
Although the crew numbers are reduced on our ships, repairs and maintenance are ongoing and there will be nominal cost when units return to work. 2018 appears promising for the seventh-generation ultra-deepwater market, assuming commodity prices can maintain their stability and as many are forecasting continue to climb steadily as the year progresses. We are actively participating in tenders for work in East and West Africa, Central and south America and the U.S. Gulf of Mexico. Additionally, we are encouraged by the activity in the recently completed bidding rounds in Mexico and the anticipated offers in Brazil, which include the second production sharing round and the 14th bidding round of blocks under the concession regime. Despite this anticipated demand, recovery for the floater market as a whole seems to be more in the 2019 timeframe.
As I alluded earlier on the call, I would like to spend a few minutes discussing attrition, both for floaters and jack-ups. On the floater side, approximately 74 units have been removed from the fleet since October of 2014. While this is a good start, given our view of demand over the coming years, we believe that an additional 100 units could be retired from the current fleet. In tandem with strengthening commodity process that encourage increased demand, this attrition could accelerate the industry's ability to obtain a healthy utilization target of 85%. The majority of these retirements should come from older units, those that are currently stacked and those that are off contract. As technology has advanced, many of these floaters have become obsolete and contractors will struggle to maintain them and put them back to work.
Regarding jack-up attrition, only 32 units have been removed from the fleet over the same time period. But there are currently 230 jack-ups in the total fleet that are 35 years or older, 62 of which are cold stacked or out of service. While it is significantly less expensive, the stacked jack-ups and floaters, which contributes to the rationale of delayed attrition, we believe that most of these older units will not reenter the market. With approximately 100 newbuilds waiting to enter the fleet, it's hard to imagine a customer choosing an aged jack-up that has been stacked for a significant amount of time over a newbuild unit for a potential project, provided a suitable drilling contractor's sponsoring their market entry.
Applying similar analysis for supportable jack-up supply in the future, we believe many of the older jack-ups could be retired from the current fleet over the coming years. No one has been diligent in our attrition efforts, having removed 4 of our older units in the market since the downturn and we will most likely retire the program in California. Attrition has accelerated recovery of the offshore drilling market, and considering the aging fleet, this is certainly an obtainable goal. 
While we acknowledge the uphill battle that the industry faces in 2017, our high spec fleet of jack-ups and drillships, backed by our outstanding workforce, gives us the utmost confidence in our ability to take advantage of the opportunities that the recovery will bring. 
This concludes my remarks this morning, and I will now turn the call over to Steve.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. On the call today, I will review our fourth quarter 2016 operating results compared to the prior quarter. Next, I'll provide some additional color around our agreement with Saudi Aramco to jointly form a new dr
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. On the call today, I will review our fourth quarter 2016 operating results compared to the prior quarter. Next, I'll provide some additional color around our agreement with Saudi Aramco to jointly form a new drilling company in 2017 and implication for our financial results. Lastly, we will provide you with an update to our cost and capital spending guidance before opening the call for questions and answers.
This morning, we reported a fourth quarter net loss of $24 million or $0.19 per share, which includes a $33.6 million loss on the extinguishment of $464 million of debt. Excluding this item, earnings were $0.08 per share for the fourth quarter, down $0.22 from the previous quarter non-GAAP earnings per share due primarily to a reduction in jack-up utilization. 
We generated $346 million in revenue during the fourth quarter, excluding the billable item, an 8% decline from the previous quarter as we incurred increased jack-up idle time in a couple of rigs out of service in the Middle East. 
We completed 26 team [ph] of less than 1.5% operational downtime [indiscernible] wide for the entire year. We are especially proud that we have not incurred any downtime on our drill [indiscernible] for 3 straight quarters and less than 1/10 of 1% downtime for the year. 
Our idle days, as a percentage of available days, showed only a slight 2% increase from the third quarter, up to approximately 29%. Our average service time for the Jack-up fleet was approximately 7% of our available rig days in the fourth quarter due primarily to repairs and inspections on the Bob Palmer and [indiscernible] and upgrades in J.P. Bussell in preparation for the contribution to the new joint venture with Saudi Aramco.
Fourth quarter operating expenses were $174 million, a reduction of $8 million from the previous quarter, attributable to lower activity on idle rigs and continued [indiscernible] effort. As a reminder, this excludes rebillable items which are offset by a commensurate increase in revenue.
In line with our guidance, SG&A expenses totaled $26 million in the fourth quarter and $102 million for the full year, down 12% from 2015 level and 19% versus 2014 [ph]. 
Our fourth quarter depreciation expense remained with the third quarter level at $102 million. Interest expense was $39 million in the quarter. 
With respect to the income tax provision, we recognized a tax benefit in the quarter of $9.7 million as a result of a reduction in our tax asset valuation allowance due to certain intercompany transactions. Our annual effective tax rate was still in the low single digit, as previously guided. 
Now for a look at our cash flow and balance sheet. For the fourth quarter, capital expenditures totaled $29 million, slightly above the third quarter level, primarily due to regularly scheduled surveys for the Bob Palmer and Hank Boswell and preparations for the J.P. Bussell's contribution to the joint venture with Saudi Aramco. 
Full year CapEx for 2016 came in at $118 million, somewhat below our previous guidance and some capital spend slipped into 2017.
All in all, we generated $218 million in cash in the fourth quarter and our current cash balance today stands at $1.1 billion. With an additional $1.5 billion on capital revolver, our liquidity continues to be very strong. 
In the fourth quarter, we issued $500 million of 8.5-year senior unsecured notes with a [ph] yield 7 3/8. Simultaneously, we executed a tender offer, focused on clearing out a substantial portion of our near-term debt maturity. Following the expiration of our tender offer, on February 8 of this year, we also exercised our early redemption option on the remaining 2017 note. In total, we extinguished approximately $590 million of debt maturity that were slated to come due between 2017 and 2022. The combined effect of these actions significantly extends our already lengthy visible runway, we believe solidifying our liquidity well into eventual market recovery and affording us the flexibility to make more opportunistic capital allocation decisions. 
Now I'd like to take some time to walk you through some of the economics of the new company that we are forming together with Saudi Aramco.
Upon legal formation late in the first quarter of 2017, Saudi Aramco and Rowan will each contribute $25 million in cash to capitalize the new entity. Shortly thereafter on startup, Saudi Aramco will also contribute 2 Jack-up rigs and related assets. Rowan will contribute 3 of its Jack-up rigs, the Gilbert Rowe, Bob Keller and J.P. Bussell, our surveys facilities and related assets. Due to the uneven value of these contributions, Saudi Aramco is expected to contribute cash to maintain a 50-50 ownership split. Day rates for these first 5 contributed rigs have been negotiated for the first 3 years into 2020.
The end dates of the current contracts on the Scooter Yeargain and Hank Boswell has been leveled out for the ramp-up simultaneously in October 2018 when these rigs will also be contributed to the new company. This adjustment contract will still provide the same backlog to Rowan between the 2 rigs. 
As with the initial contribution, Saudi Aramco is then expected to contribute cash to maintain its ownership level. The second tranche of contributed rigs, the Scooter Yeargain and Hank Boswell, will receive initial contracts of 3 years with day rates [indiscernible] discounted market index. The 7 contributed rigs, 5 initial [ph] and 2 i 2018 are expected to remain under contract for the remaining [indiscernible] to meet Saudi Aramco's drilling needs, provided that the rigs continue to meet the technical and operational requirements for Saudi Aramco. 
You will note that the contributed rigs from Rowan's side do not account for all those rigs currently under contract with Saudi Aramco. From startup, the new company will manage Rowan's 7 remaining Jack-ups in the kingdom through the remainder of their contract for a customary management fee. At the conclusion of each managed rig contract, other than the Boswell and Yeargain, which will be contributed, the rig may be leased by the new company as needed. 
Looking beyond the next few years, the new company will begin ordering Jack-ups to be built by a joint venture between Lamprell, a highly qualified and experienced player in rig construction and Saudi Aramco. We expect the first rig to be delivered in 2021, generally followed by 2 rigs per year for 10 years and up to 20 new build rigs in total. Each of these rigs will be placed on an initial long-term contract with Saudi Aramco. In a similar fashion to the contributed rig, following their initial contract, the newbuild rigs will remain under contract for the remaining useful lives at day rates determined by a discounted market index.
Although we're not providing details of all the economic arrangement, the newbuild rigs are expected to be generating attractive return on investment. I want to reinforce that both Saudi Aramco and Rowan expect the newbuild program to be fully funded through internal JV cash generation and external debt financing.
Given the magnitude of the backlog, coupled with the strength of our counterparty, we expect the new company will be able to self- and externally fund the growth without additional shareholder injection.
However, should this fund be insufficient, Saudi Aramco and Rowan intend to stand behind these orders. 
Both of the parties expect that the new company will generally not hold excess levels of cash other than what will be needed under the business plan. Any additional funds will typically be distributed to the shareholders. Therefore, given Saudi Aramco's massive contribution and the cash generation from the new entity, we expect to see a further strengthening of Rowan's already robust liquidity over the next 2 years as excess cash is distributed.
We expect account for our investment in the JV under the equity method and our share of the ventures income will flow through equity and unconsolidated subsidiary on our income statement.
As we are contributing our [indiscernible] shore base operations and facilities, those costs will also be absorbed by the new venture [indiscernible] forward. Though the intent is to create a self-sustaining business, the new company is expected to rely on Rowan for various back office support services for the first few years. We expect the reimbursement of these services to be recorded as revenue on Rowan's book. 
Now, to review our guidance for 2017, updated from our preliminary numbers provided in the last quarter. On the heels of 2 very strong years for cash generation, the next 2 years will be much more challenging in terms of our financial results, with 2 drill [indiscernible] currently idle and 1 additional backhaul potentially approaching end of its contract next quarter. As Tom and Mark discussed, while we anticipate reaching a bottom in demand for Jack-ups in 2017 and floaters in early 2018, we believe the industry will need to rationalize significant excess capacity before we experience a meaningful recovery in day rate. 
We estimate that our full year 2017 operating costs, excluding rebillable, will range between $625 million and $675 million, depending on the level of activity for our idled rigs or idle rigs rolling off contract during [ph] the year. This represents an 11% to 17% reduction from our 2016 level, primarily due to reduced activity, the new joint venture absorbing approximately $25 million of shore-based cost and incremental cost control measures. 
First quarter 2017 operating expenses are expected to be approximate $170 million. This guidance excludes certain potential joint venture costs that may be grossed up on our income statement and offset by equal revenue.
We expect incur SG&A expense of $95 million to $100 million in 2017, which represents a slight decline from the 2016 level of $102 million with approximately $26 million in the first quarter. 
We expect to record depreciation expense of $385 million to $395 million, slightly below our 2016 level. 
Our full year interest expense guidance is $155 million to $160 million, slightly above our previous guidance, taking into account the impact of the recent capital market transaction.
Moving on to our income tax provision. As pretax income declines to a fairly low level, the effective tax rate starts becoming less meaningful. For this year, instead of providing you with an estimated tax rate, we will provide guidance for the estimated tax expense. We expect our income tax expense for 2017 will approximate $50 million versus only $5 million in 2016. The significant expected difference from 2016 to 2017 is primarily driven by 2 noncash factors. Under U.S. GAAP, certain transactions that occurred in 2016, while creating no income tax in aggregate, created a tax benefit in 2016 which will be offset by expense in 2017 and 2018. Additionally, yearly [ph] adoption of the new accounting standard will result in our eliminating a deferred tax liability and taking into retained earnings over $200 million in January of 2017 but will eliminate a roughly annual $20 million benefit over the next decade.
First quarter tax expense is expected to range from $10 million to $15 million. 
Our income tax expense would like vary significantly quarter to quarter, depending on the actual results, additional backlog, additions or other transactions as they impact our forecast and our valuation allowances on our net deferred tax asset. So while the provision may be remain volatile, we expect our cash taxes to remain flat, in the $40 million range range, in 2017, excluding the impact of audits or settlements related to previous year.
Finally, we expect to incur capital expenditures of approximately $105 million to $115 million in 2017, an approximate 10% increase from previous guidance, primarily due to the deferral of certain fourth quarter capital spend into 2017.
We are proud of Rowan's performance during 2016 and the flexibility we have built for the company to maneuver through the challenging time facing our industry. Over the course of the year, we continued to reduce cost, strengthen our balance sheet and improve our liquidity without any dilution to shareholders. Our safety, environmental and drilling performance has been excellent. Our intense focus on customer satisfaction is yielding positive results, as is exemplified by our groundbreaking partnership with the world's largest oil company and consumer of Jack-up drilling rig. We are cautiously optimistic that we will see a bottom in offshore drilling activity over the next year or so and will then begin the road back towards healthy market fundamental. 
Meanwhile, it we continue to focus on what is under control as we position Rowan to thrive in the eventual market recovery. We're now prepared to open the call for questions. Operator?

They're a great customers of ours, and like I said, they've been very successful. So we're hopeful that their Deepwater program will continue.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: So you guys spent all that time towards the end of the year working on your liquidity and so now of course the natural progression, the conversation is to talk about how you're going to spend all that cash, right? So I guess you've answered the question o
componenttext: So you guys spent all that time towards the end of the year working on your liquidity and so now of course the natural progression, the conversation is to talk about how you're going to spend all that cash, right? So I guess you've answered the question on distressed assets. But I guess, looking forward further out, how would you prioritize incremental debt repurchases with this 20 22s or 24s, would that be a higher priority compared to say another extension to the revolver? And then, I guess, near term, just thinking about, as the increase are looking better, how do we feel about capital upgrades to maybe improve some of the portions of the fleet to try to improve your opportunities at near term?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first question and then I'll let Stephen answer the more difficult first one. As far as incremental upgrade to the fleet, I don't think there's a lot of things that we need to do to our core of fleet. I mean some of the older assets which
componenttext: I'll answer the first question and then I'll let Stephen answer the more difficult first one. As far as incremental upgrade to the fleet, I don't think there's a lot of things that we need to do to our core of fleet. I mean some of the older assets which are noncompetitive, we've sold there's about a couple of years, and we've got another 2 assets called stack. Then maybe something that we're bidding on a contract where the customer wants something specific but which we don't have in one of our rigs, but generally that would be a smaller amount. But as far as saying taking our fleet and saying we don't like this rig, we need to turn it into something else, that is much less likely to happen because the rigs that we have in our fleet are pretty strong. And we're still [indiscernible] doing a major capital upgrade on any of them. [indiscernible] specifically for a customer demand it pretty I'd say pretty [indiscernible].

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Sean, in terms of those priorities, wish we could share that with you, but of course you can imagine that those priorities are constantly shifting, depending on the terms of all those opportunities at any given time. So certainly, prioritize those int
componenttext: And Sean, in terms of those priorities, wish we could share that with you, but of course you can imagine that those priorities are constantly shifting, depending on the terms of all those opportunities at any given time. So certainly, prioritize those internally, but it gets only shifts in real time. And it's important for us to be flexible and we pride ourselves on being nimble, so we'll continue to assess all those opportunities and move appropriately in a way that creates the most shareholder value.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay, that's entirely fair. Just one quick one, more for Mark. I thought your comments about West Africa were pretty interesting. Perhaps, the net rig count stays challenge but high grading could lead to some incremental opportunities for you all.
componenttext: Got it, okay, that's entirely fair. Just one quick one, more for Mark. I thought your comments about West Africa were pretty interesting. Perhaps, the net rig count stays challenge but high grading could lead to some incremental opportunities for you all. Maybe you can expand on that a little bit.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sean, we're looking at some opportunities at the West Coast of Africa. The fleet there is a whole Jack-up fleet is '80s vintage, maybe '90s with some minor upgrades. So the operators are looking to high grade that fleet I think over the next couple o
componenttext: Yes, Sean, we're looking at some opportunities at the West Coast of Africa. The fleet there is a whole Jack-up fleet is '80s vintage, maybe '90s with some minor upgrades. So the operators are looking to high grade that fleet I think over the next couple of years. We've had several discussions with multiple operators about this process. And it's a little hard to pinpoint when it will actually start, but we're hopeful we'll see some of this stuff this year. But there's definitely an interest from the IOCs and NOCs to upgrade their fleet in West Jack-up fleet in West Africa.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from Ian McPherson with the Simmons and Company.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hey, Stephen, you provided a very helpful framework for how this joint venture is going to unfold, but we do have a lot of blanks to fill in with the numbers. And can you talk a little bit more about what the roadmap is for the incremental disclosure on s
componenttext: Hey, Stephen, you provided a very helpful framework for how this joint venture is going to unfold, but we do have a lot of blanks to fill in with the numbers. And can you talk a little bit more about what the roadmap is for the incremental disclosure on some of these numbers going forward, what level of transparency we can expect to get around the day rates, the expenditures for the newbuilds and all that good stuff?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ian, that's a good question. And as you know, we've been very transparent over the years, and we pride ourselves on that. But of course, we have a joint venture partner here [indiscernible] as well. And we'll continue to disclose what's required. No
componenttext: Sure, Ian, that's a good question. And as you know, we've been very transparent over the years, and we pride ourselves on that. But of course, we have a joint venture partner here [indiscernible] as well. And we'll continue to disclose what's required. Now in terms of the road map, most other thing I would say too is that much of this is going to be very visible in our financial results because it is a pretty significant JV that's going to be growing over time. So will be visible soon. And we will be filing our 10-K shortly and there will be additional disclosure with that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017

componenttext: All Right. Well...

componenttext: We think those disclosures will be helpful to you in evaluating this JV program.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good, that's sort of what I was anticipating. Mark, can you talk about the Deepwater project bucket, it's still present but it is slipping a little bit and project starts slipping from '17 and '18. And you said you see the recovery for floaters looking mo
componenttext: Good, that's sort of what I was anticipating. Mark, can you talk about the Deepwater project bucket, it's still present but it is slipping a little bit and project starts slipping from '17 and '18. And you said you see the recovery for floaters looking more like a 2019 event. But could we interpret that as maybe contract visibility and even contract awards commencing over the next 12 months or so in anticipation of that unfolding? And when you say a recovery, I would imagine more of a rebalancing of utilization by '19, is that a good interpretation of your comments?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right, Ian. We operate -- we feel like we're operating in a market with 32 ships with the dual stack 1,257 [ph] ships. And I think, we're hoping that supply and demand, certainly, hopefully come into balance, depending on commodity process, by
componenttext: Yes, that's right, Ian. We operate -- we feel like we're operating in a market with 32 ships with the dual stack 1,257 [ph] ships. And I think, we're hoping that supply and demand, certainly, hopefully come into balance, depending on commodity process, by then. But before that occurs, we're going to see some tenders, and we're going to respond to tenders. We currently have about 5 in house Deepwater tenders that we're working on and there's some others that are coming. So we're going to be very careful how we approach those. But I think, a good indicator for us, we believe, as I said earlier, we believe Jack-up market will trough in '17. A good indicator for the Deepwater market beginning to trough is when the IOCs come out for long-term contracts. I just don't think they're going to let this pricing opportunity pass without coming out with 3- to 5-year contracts, particularly the big IOCs that have enough backlog and wells to do that. So I think that's going to be your best indicator of when things would start.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Kurt Hallead with RBC.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Kurt Hallead with RBC.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: I guess, my question, on the market dynamics more broadly. It seems now very consensus view that there is substantial enough indication of demand for the Jack-up market. That's kind of been hashed out. You guys referenced the prospect though that there is
componenttext: I guess, my question, on the market dynamics more broadly. It seems now very consensus view that there is substantial enough indication of demand for the Jack-up market. That's kind of been hashed out. You guys referenced the prospect though that there is still more supply than demand in that dynamic. So how much additional pricing pressure would there potentially be? And I mean in the context do you expect to see market rates to drift down toward cash breakeven? Or do you think the cycle and the demand dynamics will be sufficient enough to keep partly operating in a profitable territory?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just one comment, Mark, [indiscernible] that queston which is a tough one. I would say it often depends, we will see certain [indiscernible] where we will see some stronger pricing. And you saw some good fixtures in the [indiscernible] gas in Saudi Arabia
componenttext: Just one comment, Mark, [indiscernible] that queston which is a tough one. I would say it often depends, we will see certain [indiscernible] where we will see some stronger pricing. And you saw some good fixtures in the [indiscernible] gas in Saudi Arabia. It seems good fixture for us in its downturn Trinidad with the LeTourneau's type rigs which are particularly suited for that. I think it will be -- I don't think we'll see any pricing recovery for quite some time. And I do think feel like management teams want to get that, maintain capabilities, they will take opportunities at lower rates. Although but I think most management teams don't want to be cash negative when they look at it from sort of a holistic CapEx, shore-based port and operating rig operating cost. I feel like we'll see some more pressure, it's hard to say how much will go down. Mark, what do you think?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Kurt, I agree with Tom. Every market in the world is different. The pricing is different in every one of those markets. But inside of those markets, the class of rigs is what's going to drive it. Commodity rigs in certain markets are at cash cost today or
componenttext: Kurt, I agree with Tom. Every market in the world is different. The pricing is different in every one of those markets. But inside of those markets, the class of rigs is what's going to drive it. Commodity rigs in certain markets are at cash cost today or below. We've seen some of them. But the higher spec rigs in different markets, such as Trinidad, Middle East and other areas, you're seeing day rates with good margins on them. And I think a good market fixture or indicator is the 2 contracts Noble signed with Saudi Aramco at 1 59. And those are 5-year term. If Saudi Aramco haven't dealt with them since 2004, I can tell you, Saudi Aramco would not contract unless they felt like the bottom of the market was near or certainly was here. And they feel like they want to maintain those high spec rigs and what take the chance [indiscernible]. So I think that's a good market indicator. Our rigs a little are shorter-term on Trinidad. But once again, good margins on them. As we roll our rigs in the Middle East, I think you'll see some good fixtures and some of our peers as they begin as they renegotiate contracts with them Saudi Aramco.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Follow up on the Deepwater market rate as we are getting indications of increased inquiry levels and more likely the prospect of incremental contract awards in 2018. What kind of strategic or tactical view are you guys going to take if you get a 3-year, 5
componenttext: Follow up on the Deepwater market rate as we are getting indications of increased inquiry levels and more likely the prospect of incremental contract awards in 2018. What kind of strategic or tactical view are you guys going to take if you get a 3-year, 5-year contract offer and you know that demand's going up? Are you going to want to stay at the shorter end of that? Maybe even just take a one-year deal and kind of try to catch the next uptake? Just curious on how you might be approaching that dynamic.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's something that we deliberate over quite a lot internally, and what we think we're going to do maybe different to what we're going to do, what we'd like to do. But I would say, that it often it would kind of depend on particular rig and how many
componenttext: Yes, it's something that we deliberate over quite a lot internally, and what we think we're going to do maybe different to what we're going to do, what we'd like to do. But I would say, that it often it would kind of depend on particular rig and how many available units we have. So if we have 1 available unit, we'll less likely take a lower cost a lower rate [indiscernible] period. If we have 3 of that class, we maybe consider something like that. Mark.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Kurt, I do think that you will see the IOCs, as I mentioned earlier, would be I don't think you'll see come out up and try to term op some of the higher spec drill ships at lower day rates. There really hasn't been any appreciable exploration drillin
componenttext: Yes, Kurt, I do think that you will see the IOCs, as I mentioned earlier, would be I don't think you'll see come out up and try to term op some of the higher spec drill ships at lower day rates. There really hasn't been any appreciable exploration drilling since early 2014. So at some point, when that begins to occur and they have these backlogs log of wells, I think you will be tempted with that opportunity. But to your question, if we see the market improving and the fact that we're doing in awe believe as IOCs term up, that they will go for the 32 dual stack, 450 ton rigs, I do think we'll be cognizant of that certainly and be cautious. We would try to contract the rig short-term rather than long-term once we see the market start to move. But that's what we see right now. I mean I can't say that changes if you have all of your the Deepwater rig is down, then you may go take one of those jobs and then play the market with the other 3 or something like that. But right now, that's kind of where we are.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then on the Saudi JV. What's the -- you said the discounted market index rate or something, what is that a global Jack-up market index that is going to be used? Or is it a regional one for just the Middle East.
componenttext: And then on the Saudi JV. What's the -- you said the discounted market index rate or something, what is that a global Jack-up market index that is going to be used? Or is it a regional one for just the Middle East.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017

componenttext: It's a global [ph] 1, but it excludes very high end markets such as Norway.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Eduardo Royes with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eduardo Royes with Jefferies.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Question for you on the drillships, depending on what happened obviously with Cobalt and Rowan may work a little bit longer. But you could end up obviously if that one goes down, that will be your third week that doesn't have a job. How should we think ab
componenttext: Question for you on the drillships, depending on what happened obviously with Cobalt and Rowan may work a little bit longer. But you could end up obviously if that one goes down, that will be your third week that doesn't have a job. How should we think about the though process around stacking from one of those. If your sense job is 3 months out, do you have to keep the same fully crewed and hot? Sort of what's the threshold worth to bring it down on 1 stack and then bring it back up? Or do you feel like that actually put you at a competitive disadvantage with customers, then maybe literally want every single guy that just finished the prior program on the rig. How should we think about the potential thought process for that rig, concerning that you probably want 1 pretty ready to go kind of bullet in the gun, if you will.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Mark, I do think we have some given that we have seventh generation or late next generation rigs, there's the only ones we have on the floating side. If certainly the lowest stack we would go down to would be 1 stack. Because if we have some low fifth-gen
componenttext: Mark, I do think we have some given that we have seventh generation or late next generation rigs, there's the only ones we have on the floating side. If certainly the lowest stack we would go down to would be 1 stack. Because if we have some low fifth-generation or low sixth generation rigs, we would certainly maybe consider taking them down lower. But 1 stack would be the lowest readiness we would go to. Most of the customers we're talking about this type of program, they don't really like spring like tomorrow. There's normally a good fair amount of lead time which is not necessarily untrue of Jack-ups. But with these water rigs, it's less likely they'll say, we'll have a rig, let's go. There normally will be 6 months, 9 months of lead time. And so we feel that keeping all of the junior crews on the rigs, meaning keep it hot stacked, if we don't have something which we can see moving to, Mark described it as walking the rig between contracts, then we would go down to a hot stack basis. So it would be kind of less likely to keep it hot stacked unless we have something clear to go to. Otherwise, we take it down to 1 stack. And when we say 1 stack, and we really 1 stack meaning it is 1, we're not expecting any additional capital to go back to work beyond the understand written operations and core marketing is at the rig can be move moved anywhere at very short notice. And it is all the maintenance team [indiscernible] customer inspect it, they will find a rig that is ready to go back to work except it doesn't have the Junior crews. So I don't see us keeping a rig hot stack on unless we had something fairly substantial. But our 1 stack is -- it is truly warm where we can our Virginia cruise tech.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add to that is our customer base has been extremely clear that if you cold stack a drillship or a Deepwater rig -- ultra Deepwater with, you'll be at significant disadvantage in securing work with them and could be eliminated from t
componenttext: The only thing I would add to that is our customer base has been extremely clear that if you cold stack a drillship or a Deepwater rig -- ultra Deepwater with, you'll be at significant disadvantage in securing work with them and could be eliminated from the bid list. So it's a different playing field today than it has been in past troughs. So they're really focused on.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got you. Actually, Mark, my follow-up is for you. Just if you could give a little bit of color on 2 pretty key markets. We saw obviously, the Central America, the Trinidad rigs recently the get some short-term incentives. Is there especially as it it look
componenttext: Got you. Actually, Mark, my follow-up is for you. Just if you could give a little bit of color on 2 pretty key markets. We saw obviously, the Central America, the Trinidad rigs recently the get some short-term incentives. Is there especially as it it looks like maybe we'll start to see more term in the Jack-up market, what are sort of how should we think about the possibility for you guys to continue to run those 3 rigs say on a the longer term basis? Or there in all likelihood demand well beyond just this year you think for to be able to run 3 rigs in that market or the industry in general? And then I guess, quickly on non Saudi Middle East, do you still think there's potentially opportunity to place 1 of your idle rigs to work in some non-Saudi market in the region this year?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Talk about Trinidad first. Trinidad's been a great market for us. We've been there since the 1970s off and on. But it's they the projects that the rigs are drilling are very visible projects within those companies. And so right now, it's very hard to
componenttext: Yes. Talk about Trinidad first. Trinidad's been a great market for us. We've been there since the 1970s off and on. But it's they the projects that the rigs are drilling are very visible projects within those companies. And so right now, it's very hard to speculate on how long they will keep the rigs. We've been told that there's a lot of work for them in the region. So we're very focused on that. Our operations team has done a great job from an operation standpoint. But right now, I think there is work beyond '17 in Trinidad for those rigs. But without firm commitment, it's very difficult to make that claim to you. But they are very visible projects for the operators that we're currently working for. In the Middle East and the UAE and Qatar, we're seeing some demand there for jack-ups, the EXL I and IV certainly tendered there. We're tendering those rigs all over the world. But we are seeing some demand both in Qatar and in the UAE. Those type of rigs preferred type of rig in that region.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Separately, Mark, you mentioned the supply pressure from the newbuilds that are in the shipyard still. And I guess, I'm just curious on the Jack-up side there is, I'm curious if you've noticed those rigs are actually showing up and competing for work somehow? Or is the fact that out of the money that they kind of just shadow supply for the time being?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 24, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think that what we're seeing in the market is that if it's a established drilling contractor, certainly, they're going to bring their rigs in and [indiscernible]. We've seen a few of those. And that will replace older assets in regions. But in Southeast
componenttext: I think that what we're seeing in the market is that if it's a established drilling contractor, certainly, they're going to bring their rigs in and [indiscernible]. We've seen a few of those. And that will replace older assets in regions. But in Southeast Asia, we've seen a couple of things from newbuilds that that's where most of them are being constructed, so there are obviously less. But [indiscernible] a little less strict on into that market. But in other regions, we haven't really seen it. We haven't  certainly not with Aramco, they have stringent requirements for entry in Qatar and UAE. So we haven't seen a lot of that because to qutoe a lot of our customers, if an established contractor has a rig available which most of new, they're going to go that direction because of obvious concerns about downtime and startup and things like that, safety, the major things that they should be thinking about. So anyway, we haven't seen in abundance of that became.

componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Tom. I can't speak to Saudi Aramco, but I could just give you a couple of thoughts about what they've said publicly. I think that the Saudi Aramco is very focused on  Saudi Arabia's very focused on a number of items. One is the creation of n
componenttext: Mark, this is Tom. I can't speak to Saudi Aramco, but I could just give you a couple of thoughts about what they've said publicly. I think that the Saudi Aramco is very focused on  Saudi Arabia's very focused on a number of items. One is the creation of new industries. And so I think there's a big project for a shipyard. And the shipyard is not just focused on jack-ups. It's a large capital investment. And the call the maritime-ing maritime initiative and kind of search on Google and there's been some press releases on it. And it's going to build platform, it's going to build ships, it's got bulk ships, tankers, it's going to build a lot of different assets, including offshore rig, jack-up rigs. And so I believe that one of the focuses of the JV is perhaps of our partnership with them is to have a customer for those assets, that's one. And I think there will also, again I can't speak to Saudi Aramco, but I think there will be focused of diversifying their economy away from just [indiscernible] and the other biggest in the world from a number of different metrics around hydrocarbon. But also focus on another developing other part of their economy and so, I think that's a part of it. And also they have a big focus on work force development. So I think those are main reasons, I can't speak for them as I can just  But they have a number of interesting information around that 20-30 vision in their kingdom total value add plant.
