componenttextpreview: I think one of them is in Norway. And obviously, the N-Class rig has -- that rig has an AoC. And I can't actually offhand, David, remember the water depth. But one of the rigs is in Norway on another program. And it came on in Norway, which is good. And t
componenttext: I think one of them is in Norway. And obviously, the N-Class rig has -- that rig has an AoC. And I can't actually offhand, David, remember the water depth. But one of the rigs is in Norway on another program. And it came on in Norway, which is good. And the other rig, though, is in U.K. sector on accommodation. I would say that, again, nothing specifically, I can't remember the water depth, frankly.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Dave, the Stavanger worked for Talisman when it came out of the yard, which as you know was acquired by Repsol. So they're very familiar with Stavanger. As Tom said, has an AoC. And the rig is set up to do this type of work. And then in the U.K., we've be
componenttext: Dave, the Stavanger worked for Talisman when it came out of the yard, which as you know was acquired by Repsol. So they're very familiar with Stavanger. As Tom said, has an AoC. And the rig is set up to do this type of work. And then in the U.K., we've been on that platform to work with similar rigs. And so it just worked out for us, familiarity of our operations team and our rigs. So it worked well.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: And that N-Class rig has got a large accommodation, an excellent, well-built, modern rig, which I think Talisman Sinopec -- Repsol Sinopec really liked and have used before.
componenttext: And that N-Class rig has got a large accommodation, an excellent, well-built, modern rig, which I think Talisman Sinopec -- Repsol Sinopec really liked and have used before.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Makes sense. I noticed that almost 40% of the jack-ups certified for Norway aren't in Norway. And I was wondering if you see any transition cost or obstacles that suggest that some of those rigs outside of Norway might need a higher day rate to earn the s
componenttext: Makes sense. I noticed that almost 40% of the jack-ups certified for Norway aren't in Norway. And I was wondering if you see any transition cost or obstacles that suggest that some of those rigs outside of Norway might need a higher day rate to earn the same margin as an in-country rig.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think the N-Class rigs are very flexible rigs, can be used -- could be used anywhere in the world. But frankly, they are well suited for the North Sea given the winterization on them and the way that they're built. But that said, they just can be used a
componenttext: I think the N-Class rigs are very flexible rigs, can be used -- could be used anywhere in the world. But frankly, they are well suited for the North Sea given the winterization on them and the way that they're built. But that said, they just can be used anywhere in the world, but they are well-built for the North Sea. If we were to use them elsewhere, they are a very highly automated rig, so the customer -- so it would be able to practically do anything. But those rigs are -- and we bid them in other parts of the world, but they're very good North Sea rigs. I'd tell you, the Gorilla is probably the rig that we'd more likely take other places. And we have a Super Gorilla working in the Arabian Gulf right now. Super Gorillas have worked in Canada, Angola, Gulf of Mexico. So Super Gorillas are more likely to work elsewhere. And they would have a -- they're a big rig with 5 cranes. So that they're more likely -- customers often like to put a bit more crew on them so they can get to use the full capabilities of the enormous sort of deck space, et cetera. So our OpEx on those rigs is often a bit higher than, say, a sort of standard Super 116E or a 240-C, but we can have a -- reduce the crew size on them and not use all the capabilities of the rig, the [ pick-ups ] , the [indiscernible] as well.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: And last for me. I had looked at the ARO agreement and I just wanted to check my understanding of whether Rowan is obligated to order some new jack-ups built in Saudi. And if so, what the time line on that would look like?
componenttext: And last for me. I had looked at the ARO agreement and I just wanted to check my understanding of whether Rowan is obligated to order some new jack-ups built in Saudi. And if so, what the time line on that would look like?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rowan outside of the JV is not obligated to build -- to order jack-ups. But what we did agree is that if we were to order some jack-ups and the JV was able to build just -- and this is a -- I'm just thinking back a year ago or so or 2 years ago. But
componenttext: Yes, Rowan outside of the JV is not obligated to build -- to order jack-ups. But what we did agree is that if we were to order some jack-ups and the JV was able to build just -- and this is a -- I'm just thinking back a year ago or so or 2 years ago. But from memory, if Rowan were to be ordering jack-ups and the JV were to -- and the maritime JV were to be able to deliver a jack-up at a competitive price and a competitive quality, then we would give the maritime yard preference. But outside of the 20 rigs, we are -- ARO Drilling, we don't have an obligation. But we certainly are going to spend an awful lot of time and effort in that maritime shipyard over the next several years. And we believe that Lamprell and HHI are both first class.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mike Urban from Seaport.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: So there were a number of contractors out there, a number of your competitors that were of the view that if you had an asset that was stacked or an undelivered newbuild that had been delayed, that those effectively were out of the competitive supply stack
componenttext: So there were a number of contractors out there, a number of your competitors that were of the view that if you had an asset that was stacked or an undelivered newbuild that had been delayed, that those effectively were out of the competitive supply stack, at least until the hot rigs or the warm rigs went back to work. And so obviously, we've seen a few contracts out there for multiple contractors that have been able to get a stacked rig to work and deliver an uncontracted newbuild. Obviously, rates not disclosed, but would seem to be -- it's kind of on an all-in basis cash neutral at best, maybe cash negative. One, do you think those are somewhat unique situations or one-offs? Or is that something we could see more of? And two, does that change your view of the timing of the recovery and the market from a rate perspective?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think it's a very good question, Mike. And it's sort of like a very difficult question to answer. I do feel like some of those contracts that were -- you saw were definitely -- were contracts where there was an NOC partner. I'm not exactly understanding
componenttext: I think it's a very good question, Mike. And it's sort of like a very difficult question to answer. I do feel like some of those contracts that were -- you saw were definitely -- were contracts where there was an NOC partner. I'm not exactly understanding how that works, but I do think that typically, with certain NOCs, basically the lowest technically qualified bid wins. So if you're technically qualified, if you have an early gen, sixth generation -- if it's early gen, sixth-generation rig is qualified and you bid the lowest, I think you'll get it, basically, is my understanding.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. That's right.
componenttext: Yes. That's right.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I also think that some of the rigs in the shipyard, I would say that, what we've always maintained is customers would like newbuilds, would like hot rigs. They would like warm rigs and pretty closely after that would like newbuilds. And again, I
componenttext: Yes. And I also think that some of the rigs in the shipyard, I would say that, what we've always maintained is customers would like newbuilds, would like hot rigs. They would like warm rigs and pretty closely after that would like newbuilds. And again, I think we're not -- unfortunately, we're not in that position where we have to get a newbuild out of the yard. Although, I suppose, if you're going to -- if you need to get a newbuild out of a yard, largely we are seeing them later rather than pay the yard fee -- I don't really know that -- the answer to that. But I do think -- I was -- certainly, we're not in that position. We don't have rigs in the yard. That's not an issue for us. Do I think it changed the dynamics? I believe that in the seventh-generation category, there's a limited number of them. There are, of course, rigs rolling off contract. But in the seventh-gen drillship, 2 BOPs, 1,250 ton, there aren't that many of them and a number of them are contracted. And so I feel like it probably doesn't change the -- the landscape around those rigs. But frankly, if it's a contract, you take a sixth-generation rig, an early sixth-generation rig, 1,000 ton, 1 BOP, perhaps, then there's a lot more competition, whether it's cold-stacked or not.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Vebs. That's a good question. We do have the Stavanger that's been idle for some time that's going back to work this quarter. That's the biggest piece of the increase. Now we have other costs that are -- some that are declining as well, but we've al
componenttext: Sure, Vebs. That's a good question. We do have the Stavanger that's been idle for some time that's going back to work this quarter. That's the biggest piece of the increase. Now we have other costs that are -- some that are declining as well, but we've also had some out-of-service time shift from second quarter to third quarter. So like the Mississippi and the Scooter Yeargain, for example, we're going to have higher R&M on those this quarter. So when we look at our labor cost overall, we expect it to be relatively flat in the second quarter, but we do see an increase in R&M in the third quarter. And that's our expectation today. But -- and I would note that while we have beat in a number of quarters on cost, this quarter, we came right in line with guidance. Hopefully, we'll be able to get back and beating again, but this is our expectation today. And then furthermore, I would say that we have guided to a pretty big reduction in operating cost in the fourth quarter. And if you take the midpoint of our annual guidance, that represents a pretty significant reduction in cost in the fourth quarter.

componenttext: That's fair. That's fair. And in terms of like Saudi JV timing closing, just like -- I guess, where I'm coming from is, actually, the way we were modeling is taking out the 3 rigs' revenue from the overall revenue. But obviously, it depends on when the Saudi JV closes. Could you help us there, how should we think about it?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, again, I think all we've said is third quarter. Of course, July is behind us. So I think you'll have an opportunity to refine your forecast based on the actual startup date.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Crysta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Rowan Company's Third Quarter 2017 Earning Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Burke, you
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Crysta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Rowan Company's Third Quarter 2017 Earning Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Burke, you may begin.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Welcome to Rowan's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your interest in Rowan. A company of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found on our website at rowan.com. Joining me on the call this mo
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Welcome to Rowan's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your interest in Rowan. A company of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found on our website at rowan.com. Joining me on the call this morning are Tom Burke, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Keller, Executive Vice President, Business Development; and Stephen Butz, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to remind you that expectations expressed during this conference call are forward-looking statements and are subject to risks, assumptions, trends and uncertainties, such as market conditions and the general economy, commodity prices, offshore drilling activity levels, renegotiation, early termination or cancellation of contracts, risks related to our joint venture with Saudi Aramco and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our earnings release and SEC filings on our website that more fully describe forward-looking statements, risk factors and other events that could impact future results. 
Please note that information discussed during today's call is as of now and may be outdated at the time of any replay. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom Burke, Rowan's President and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your participation today and your continued interest and investment in Rowan. Following my prepared remarks, Mark will give you an update on the offshore
componenttext:
Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, and welcome to our Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your participation today and your continued interest and investment in Rowan. 
Following my prepared remarks, Mark will give you an update on the offshore drilling market, and Stephen will walk you through our financial performance and guidance and then I'll conclude with some thoughts on ARO Drilling before opening the call for questions. 
In the third quarter, we believe Permian crude oil prices continue to help the offshore rig market find the and even make some modest improvements in some categories and regions. Interest from our customers to resume exploration drilling seems to be increasing, however, the majority of the visible demand continues to be for shorter cycle activities and mature basins. While this dynamic is supported on a gradual recovery in jack-up activity, the Deepwater floater market is much more dependent on demand from exploration drilling. Though we've seen a general increase in tendering activity in the floater market over the past quarters, we still believe incremental contract fixtures will struggle to keep pace with the cadence of contracts from rolling off through the end of 2017 and well into 2018. Regardless of the market segment, as contracts that was signed before the downturn come to an end, we have already seen a strong trend for all the rigs to be replaced by modern, more capable rigs. We expect this trends to continue, especially in the floater market were there is a strong technical differentiation in the latest generation of rigs. 
As we approach the end of the year, crude oil prices will play a vital role in E&P budget and project approvals for 2018. Mark will go through more detail about our recent contract awards, utilization trends and our outlook for the Rowan fleet. This quarter end, we announced the launch of ARO Drilling as joint venture with Saudi Aramco. I'd like to thank a moment to thank and congratulate our employees on both the Saudi Aramco to work tirelessly to ensure successful startup to ARO Drilling. It's been almost a year since we announced the signing of this historic partnership with the largest jack-up customer in the world, and we're pleased to see it fully operating. I'll go into more detail about ARO Drilling following Stephen's comments. 
This morning, we reported a net loss of $0.17 per diluted share in the third quarter from a loss of [ 23 ]% per diluted share in the previous quarter. Our third quarter adjusted EBITDA was $99 million versus the consensus estimate of approximately $83 million. We are pleased that J.P. Bussell and Rowan Norway went back to work during the quarter, improving our total jack-up utilization of 78%. Our impressive operational efficiency continues in the third quarter with approximately 99% up-time fleet-wide and exhibited ongoing capital spending discipline and control of cost, which resulted in a cash balance at quarter end of approximately $1.2 billion and a cash balance today of over $1.3 billion. As we consider capital allocation opportunities, we're mindful of maintaining an attracted credit profile and a strong solid balance sheet. We recognize the value in preserving liquidity and when we examine opportunistic investments, we believe the transactions should be strategic, accretive and not [indiscernible] the asset quality of our fleet. 
Now for more detailed look at the market, I'll hand the call over to Mark.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, we were pleased with the overall improvement in market cinema as well as the backlog additions for our jack-up fleet, most notably in Trinidad. As announced in our most recent fleet status
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, we were pleased with the overall improvement in market cinema as well as the backlog additions for our jack-up fleet, most notably in Trinidad. As announced in our most recent fleet status report, we extended our current contracts with BPE on both the Joe Douglas and the EXL II. These commitments had approximately 1-year of work for each unit. Additionally, the Ralph Coffman also secured a contract extension, which will carry the rig through the end of the year. 
Our excellence and operational performance in the region continues to lead to repeat business with valued customers. 
Also this quarter, Shell contracted the Gorilla VI forge program in Trinidad. The jack-up were mobilized from the North Sea for 153-day drilling program that is scheduled to commence in the second quarter of 2018. There are 4 priced options following the initial program, which, if exercised, would keep the rig busy until early 2019. 
As a reminder, the Gorilla VI continues to receive day rate until early March as part of the termination agreement with ConocoPhillips. The worldwide demand for harsh environment jack-ups is showing signs of health and utilization is hovering around levels that are supportive for improved commercial terms. Although demand in this subsector is improving, I should note that around half of the projects for these more capable units originates from benign environment regions with operators being attracted to the generally higher levels of efficiency that these harsh environment rig provide. The overall jack-up demand appears to have bottomed. The supply-demand balance for benign environment jack-ups continues to be extremely challenging with day rates approximating operating costs in some region. 
With the plentiful supply of modern rigs that will warm our stack, combined with substantial queue of newbuilds, it is difficult to predict when the promotional environment will improve on a global basis. This appreciation for the distinction between harsh and benign environment jack-ups is supportive of Rowan's strategy and mission statement. To be recognized by our customers as a sufficient and capable provider of demand and contract drilling services. 85% of our marketed jack-ups are high-spec with most rigs also being ready for harsh environments. Today and historically, utilization levels are higher for this caliber of rig. 
Now looking at specific jack-up regions of the world. Middle East provides significant potential for increase in demand for 2018 considering outstanding tender requirements across the region. Incremental demand is anticipated from Saudi Aramco, National Drilling Company, Kuwait Oil Company and KJO, among other customers. EXL I and EXL IV currently tendered on multiple projects in the region, and we are hopeful to secure contracts for those units over the coming quarters. 
The Bob Palmer is currently contracted to Saudi Aramco til the end of the year. Discussions are ongoing about the possible extension for this high-spec jack-up to be leased into ARO and continue a successful track record of deep gas drilling. 
The North Sea. 5 of our 6 jack-ups are currently contracted as a role in Norway recently completed a project in the U.K. with Repsol Sinopec. We are looking at multiple opportunities for the Rowan Norway and the Gorilla VI, both in and out of the region for projects starting in 2018. 
In the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, we secured a new contract with the offshore for the EXL III. But the region remains one of the weakest jack-up regions in the world. The conversations with customers have picked up slightly now that hurricane season is behind us, but continuous work may be a challenge in this market so the EXL III is also being tendered worldwide. 
Now turning to the floater market. I'd like to briefly mention recent news in Latin America before focusing on the ultra-deepwater market. We continue to actively participate in opportunities in Latin America and closely monitor the ongoing bid rounds. Last week, the high interest from and the Brazilian bidding rounds further strengthen our view that this region will have an increase in activity level in the coming years. 
In Mexico, the next round of watch will be in January of 2018, which should have closed to 30 deepwater blocks up for bid. In the broad floater market, we don't expect contracted demand to make a definitive turn til at least late 2018. There's a lack of near-term incremental projects in the face of significant continued contract run-offs in the coming months. Though fixtures are few and far between, recent contract awards support the well-equipped seventh-generation units are performed by customers, and we are actively pursuing approximately 10 to 12 prospects for our drillships. 
Programs range in link from 150 days to 3 years, and commencement dates are expected during the next 12 to 18 months. There are only 18 build stack, 1,250-ton capable units available before the end of 2018, so that niche market could tighten up well in advance of the total fleet. 
As I cautioned on the last call, continued commodity price strength for the remainder of the year will play a key role in a follow-through of plan 2018 and 2019 deepwater activity. Rowan is well positioned in the current stage of the market with high-performing shallow water assets and 4 the most capable ultra-deepwater drillships in the industry today. We are exhibiting operational excellence, acutely focused on adding backlog and strategically prepared for the recovery. 
This concludes my remarks, and I will now turn the call over to Stephen.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. In addition to reviewing our third quarter 2017 results today, I'll provide you with updates on our cost and capital spending guidance for the remainder of 2017 and provide preliminary guidance for 2018. Follow
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. In addition to reviewing our third quarter 2017 results today, I'll provide you with updates on our cost and capital spending guidance for the remainder of 2017 and provide preliminary guidance for 2018. Following my comments, I'll turn the call back over to Tom. 
As Tom mentioned, we are pleased with the recent launch of ARO Drilling. Shortly following the close of the third quarter, we received an $88 million cash distribution from arrow as part of the formation process, further bolstering our liquidity in this challenging market. Our cash balance is now over $1.3 billion. Together with our $1.5 billion revolving credit facility, this liquidity positions us very well to both weather the storm and make opportunistic investments. 
Now for our quarterly results. This morning, we reported a net loss of $21 million or $0.17 per diluted share in comparison to a net loss of $29 million or $0.23 per diluted share last quarter. Both quarters included minor impacts from the early extinguishment of debt with the third quarter including a $500,000 loss and the second quarter including a $2.4 million gain. 
The quarter-over-quarter reduction in our net loss per share was driven by an income tax benefit related to a lapse in the statute of limitations. 
Revenue for the third quarter was $289 million, excluding rebillable items, a decrease of 9% from the prior quarter due to the declining deepwater revenue. Despite the overall reduction, we were pleased to see a $6 million improvement in jack-up revenue attributed to the start-up of the JC Brussel in the Middle East and the Rowan Norway in the U.K. 
Operating costs remained relatively flat quarter-over-quarter, so our adjusted EBITDA declined to $99 million from $131 million in the second quarter of 2017, while our EBITDA margins declined to 34%. While this is now well off recent peak levels, I would add that I'm pleased that we've been able to maintain an EBITDA margin 3 years into the cyclical downturn that is equal to our EBITDA margin from the first quarter of 2014. 
Our quarterly jack-up utilization increased to 78%, up 6% from the second quarter level though average day rates decreased slightly. Our third quarter deepwater utilization was 50%, considering the revenue producing days on the Rowan Reliance where we are recognizing deferred revenue related to the Cobalt prepayment and termination in 2016. Notably, our Rowan resolute ultra-deepwater drillship once again did not incur any unbillable downtime during this [ third ] quarter. A [indiscernible] has now accomplished for 5 consecutive quarters.  Our total operational downtime, including both the floaters and jack-up fleet, was only 1%. 
Now turning to expenses. Operating cost for the third quarter were $165 million, net for rebillable item, in line with low end of our guidance and flat with the second quarter level. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect operating costs to decline to $150 million to $160 million. The expected decline is largely due to the launch of ARO Drilling and the associated sale of assets to ARO. As a reminder, this guidance excludes rebillables as well as certain potential ARO Drilling pass-through cost that we expect to have an equal offset in revenue. 
SG&A expenses for the third quarter totaled $25 million, representing a slight increase from $22 million in the second quarter, but they were at the low end of our guidance. As we mentioned in our prior call, second quarter G&A expense benefited from a reduced stock price and its impact on certain compensation awards that are mark-to-market. We anticipate our fourth quarter SG&A expense will remain relatively flat with the third quarter level. 
For the third quarter, depreciation expense totaled $103 million, and we expect full year expense of slightly higher than $400 million, just above our previous guidance due to the delayed sale of rigs to ARO Drilling. Interest expense for the third quarter was $39 million and our 2017 estimate is $156 million. 
Our full year guidance for income tax expense has been reduced to the mid-$20 million range compared to our prior guidance of the low $40 million, primarily due to a tax benefit as a result of the resolution of our prior year tax contingency. Income tax expense will likely continue to remain volatile for the foreseeable future, and tax expense will be impacted not only by levels of pretax income, but also by the timing of contract awards, changes in valuation allowance on deferred tax assets and various other factors. We continue to expect our cash tax payments during 2017 to total in the mid-$30 million range. 
Now let's discuss our cash flow and balance sheet. Capital expenditures totaled $21 million in the third quarter, $5 million below second quarter levels. We are reducing our full year guidance from $120 million to $130 million down to $120 million. We ended the quarter with just [ above ] $1.2 billion in cash before the ARO distribution. 
As previously stated, we retired $7 million of debt in the third quarter, which brings our year-to-date total debt retirement to $170 million. 
Next, I would like to provide full year guidance for 2018, keeping in mind that we are currently on our budget process, and these estimates will be refined on our next quarterly earnings call. As I mentioned last quarter, Rowan will be reimbursed by ARO Drilling for back office and operations support costs, which we will recognize as revenue as part of the transition services arrangement. 
For 2018, we expect transition services revenue to approximate $30 million, but to gradually decline thereafter over the next few years until there are no remaining transition services. Our 2018 operating expenses, excluding rebillable items, are expected to range from $600 million to $650 million. These estimates could change depending on the schedule of drilling units returning to work. 
SG&A expense for 2018 is estimated to range from $95 million to $105 million, [indiscernible] in mind with the 2017 level. 
Depreciation expense is expected to range from $370 million to $380 million and interest expense is forecast at $155 million in 2018. 
As most of our contributions to ARO were structured as shareholder loans, we also expect to generate approximately $10 million of interest income from ARO Drilling on top of interest income related to our cash balance. 
And finally, we estimate our maintenance capital expenditures will total less than $100 million in 2018. As a reminder, we are accounting for ARO Drilling under the equity method. However, we also intend to provide supplementary financial details in our earnings releases and periodic filings going forward. To assist you with your forecasting of ARO, we have disclosed the day rates on the initial 5 rigs, which ARO will collect as revenue and assume the operating costs forward. We've also disclosed the transition services cost for ARO to be paid to Rowan. 
Lastly, ARO Drilling has assumed the cost of our former Saudi Arabia shorebase. 
Now before opening the call for questions and answers, I'm going to hand the call back to Tom for some brief closing remarks.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stephen. In closing, we are excited about the launch of ARO Drilling and strongly believe that this venture will be a significant long-term growth driver for our company. The $88 million cash distribution we received in October, together with a se
componenttext:
Thanks, Stephen. In closing, we are excited about the launch of ARO Drilling and strongly believe that this venture will be a significant long-term growth driver for our company. The $88 million cash distribution we received in October, together with a second and larger distribution expected in late 2018 after we sell and the wells are examples of the immediate benefits created by this joint venture. 
However, we believe the most significant value creation from the JV is still ahead of us and will become more apparent was the newbuild rigs enter the ARO Drilling fleet. This morning, we published an appendix to our investor presentation outlawing the various components of ARO drilling. We hope this summary will help to clarify the structure and clearly illustrate the long-term value creation that we believe ARO Drilling will provide to Rowan. We believe the visible growth of ARO Drilling is a major differentiator for us in an industry that currently struggles to have much visibility and stability. 
Operator, we're now ready to turn the call over for questions.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ian MacPherson.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: You've been linked in the press with some M&A speculation, and I want to ask you to comment on that directly. But given the bifurcation that we're seeing between harsh environment assets, both from the jack-up side and the floater side, I wonder what your
componenttext: You've been linked in the press with some M&A speculation, and I want to ask you to comment on that directly. But given the bifurcation that we're seeing between harsh environment assets, both from the jack-up side and the floater side, I wonder what your view is on the durability of that trend. Whether it's sort of transient with regard to your we are in the cycle for this year maybe the next 1 or 2 years. Or if it's sufficiently structural that M&A that focuses on harsh environment jack-ups is going to be more of a priority for Rowan since we have doubled down on that fleet profile that you built today, at least from the jack-up side.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. So with respect to M&A, it's obviously hard to make specific comments. And one of my competitors [indiscernible] so and there has been, but himself so many times and nothing ever happened. So with that said, what Rowan has said were
componenttext: It's a good question. So with respect to M&A, it's obviously hard to make specific comments. And one of my competitors [indiscernible] so and there has been, but himself so many times and nothing ever happened. So with that said, what Rowan has said were as far as our perspective on M&A that we should definitely -- we look at all transaction as being a strategic accretive and to develop the asset quality of our fleet. That's our time line of how we think about individual asset transactions and how we think about our larger transactions. I would say that the other lines are to focus on that is our desire, a strong desire to improve the return on invested capital and make sure that from a capital allocation perspective, every dollar that we invest in new assets is well spent. So we are certainly focused on that. With respect to your specific question about the harsh environments jack-up market, clearly, the has been our focus for the last several years. We obviously have moved into the ultra-deepwater at the high end, but the Shire transactions that we did that we executed in 2010 was aligned with entering that market. I do think the harsh environment market is, as we think about the whole of the jack-up market, it is a bit of a big market, and the harsh environment market is a small part of it and it's definitely somewhere that Rowan need to be focused historically and something that we would definitely -- it's somewhere where we like. Now the problem is with those assets, there aren't that many compared to the large number of assets that are out there in the jack-up space. But there are some jack-ups harsh environment jack-ups in the Chinese shipyards as well. So there are some opportunities out there, but we continue to view that as an interesting market as we always have the last 5 or 6 years.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: All right. Appreciate that perspective. Just for from my follow-up. Is there any update with the jack-ups in Brazil that on an auction? That seems to be radio silent? Have you heard anything back from that?
componenttext: All right. Appreciate that perspective. Just for from my follow-up. Is there any update with the jack-ups in Brazil that on an auction? That seems to be radio silent? Have you heard anything back from that?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: Yes. We have a good dialogue with Petrobras, and they are going through their processes. It is -- it as I said, it is more what made one way or the other from our perspective or from their perspective, we certainly put our release on that. But it is that we do find it those attractive assets. As you can see now, I was at where we built those assets. So I feel like we've got a good understanding of those rigs. And no rig is perfect, that's for sure unless they have a Rowan drill ship, but no rig is perfect. But we like those assets. We know them very well and spend a year of my life [indiscernible] that project. So we're excited about it, but we have certainly having a good correspondence with Petrobras on that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Certainly glad to answer that question. We will have, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, supplementary financial details, both in our earnings release and Qs and Ks going forward. And initially, it will likely include some summary balance sheet data
componenttext: Certainly glad to answer that question. We will have, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, supplementary financial details, both in our earnings release and Qs and Ks going forward. And initially, it will likely include some summary balance sheet data as well as many of the [indiscernible] line items from the income statement. It will also be subject to a significant test. And when it reaches a certain level of significance, it will be required to provide the audited financials of ARO. So obviously, we expect the joint venture to grow dramatically, of course. As you know, our expected results for '18 and '19 are relatively weak, so it could hit that -- those levels where audits are required fairly early. So I think -- in summary, I think there will be a lot of transparency around the results.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: Okay. And I guess just from a disclosure standpoint, would you expect that a lot of the details have been in the shareholders agreement. Will those kind of just come out through the financials most likely as opposed to more explicit updates?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean, to be clear, there weren't that many items that were redacted. It would simply be the discount to market on the index rate, which, of course, we did disclose the results for on those and the return on the newbuild rigs. But really, othe
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean, to be clear, there weren't that many items that were redacted. It would simply be the discount to market on the index rate, which, of course, we did disclose the results for on those and the return on the newbuild rigs. Now and realize the newbuilds won't be first newbuild will be coming out til 2021. But, of course, certain details will probably be required in the footnotes to the financial statement. So obviously, we haven't walked through all of that yet at this point.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And I just wanted to ask on the back of, I guess, Mark's comment that you're seeing a lot more demand for harsh environment jack-ups and nonharsh environment areas. Are there -- obviously, the Gorilla VI is an example of that, but is that --
componenttext: Fair enough. And I just wanted to ask on the back of, I guess, Mark's comment that you're seeing a lot more demand for harsh environment jack-ups and nonharsh environment areas. Are there -- obviously, the Gorilla VI is an example of that, but is that -- I mean, is there really kind of a broader trend you're starting to see? And are there certain regions where this makes sense more than other areas? Or it's just kind of you can get a big beefy rig for a lower cost when you could ever pour?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It depends on a regional basis, but we've seen those rigs now where they're approaching 85% utilization, which is where the market has you're able to raise rates. And so we decided that seeing some of the demand outside of the North Sea, we thought we cou
componenttext: It depends on a regional basis, but we've seen those rigs now where they're approaching 85% utilization, which is where the market has you're able to raise rates. And so we decided that seeing some of the demand outside of the North Sea, we thought we could take some supplier in the North Sea and maybe help that situation a little bit in the North Sea from a day rate standpoint. But we are seeing stuff in West Africa, Middle East, Trinidad, certainly for those type of rigs. They're stuffing the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico. So we're monitoring every market. A lot of people thought we were crazy in the first time Tom and I said we were taking the Bob Palmer to the Middle East to market about 30 feet water. So there are opportunities that these well boars get more difficult to drill. They like the operating capability of those rigs drilling this deep extended rich wells.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the closing of the ARO JV. Can you talk to bit about -- I know in the past that there's been a potential for ARO to maybe grow a little bit faster than what is stated. So as we look at ARO today, based on what you played down on the presentati
componenttext: Congrats on the closing of the ARO JV. Can you talk to bit about -- I know in the past that there's been a potential for ARO to maybe grow a little bit faster than what is stated. So as we look at ARO today, based on what you played down on the presentation, it looks like it's just kind of plug-and-play. The cash is just going to build up over time as you fund the newbuilds. Is there anyway, just looking at the overall market in Saudi Arabia, where we could see opportunities for ARO to take advantage of where asset prices are today and maybe, I guess, accelerate their share?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, it's a good question and something we actually spent quite a bit of time on. So I'm on the Board of ARO, but I can't speak for ARO, but I would say anecdotally, I think it will be unlikely for ARO to buy these rigs because it has a significant
componenttext: Yes, Greg, it's a good question and something we actually spent quite a bit of time on. So I'm on the Board of ARO, but I can't speak for ARO, but I would say anecdotally, I think it will be unlikely for ARO to buy these rigs because it has a significant opportunity in front of it as far as the newbuild programs. So it would be less likely to buy rigs to its newbuild program. Having said that, it does seem, as per Mark's comments, that there is an opportunity for incremental demand in Saudi Arabia. We believe that ARO [indiscernible] in addition to that. Obviously, we have some uncontracted assets, but not that many. And we do believe that if there is an incremental demand in the Saudi Arabia as long as ARO is competitive and on price and it has the operational performance, we think that we have an opportunity to grow its fleet over the next several years, even before the newbuilds program starts in Saudi Arabia through the maritime JV that is just about up and running or is up and running right now.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just because it's been out in the market as bore partnership with Slumber J. Just as you think about that, I mean, it sounds like there could be other opportunities for similar type of relationships like that [indiscernible] As you l
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just because it's been out in the market as bore partnership with Slumber J. Just as you think about that, I mean, it sounds like there could be other opportunities for similar type of relationships like that [indiscernible] As you look at your drill, as you look at your floaters, I mean, you have 3 idle floaters. As you think about trying to coddle together or find work for those rigs, I mean, are you having discussions about maybe forming partnerships with other service providers to maybe give you a leg up and then trying to find that bad incremental contract for some of those quarters?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that probably most of those conversations are more directed at the jack-up markets and more. But having said that, I think there is an interest depending on the customer on that kind of packaging. I would say as far as an alliance with se
componenttext: Yes. I would say that probably most of those conversations are more directed at the jack-up markets and more. But having said that, I think there is an interest depending on the customer on that kind of packaging. I would say as far as an alliance with service companies, it's something we do talk a lot about. Haven't had a lot of discussions with companies, including Slumber J and are included on Slumber J what I think they're made it pretty clear that they're exclusive with board drilling. And also most of the release is about alliances, all that particular alliances certainly come from one side and not the other. So as I would say, we are talking across all of the service companies about how to change the business model, how to basically help our customers reduce their overall cost, while still becoming more efficient and then driving opportunities across the board with various service companies, including Slumber J. So I think it is -- there's a lot of discussion on it. Not that much actually happened yet, but I think some interest in this party.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Meakim from JPMorgan.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the M&A CapEx. Some of the recent press reports we've seen and, of course, some of your peers announced some deals. So just thought maybe it was more asking the question. Do you find a larger drill ship fleet attractive as a potential
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the M&A CapEx. Some of the recent press reports we've seen and, of course, some of your peers announced some deals. So just thought maybe it was more asking the question. Do you find a larger drill ship fleet attractive as a potential outcome to the cycle and it's simply would you maybe consider semis as part of a larger fleet quickly in the North Sea?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. No. That's a good question, Sean. I do think that on the larger rill ship fleet, I think the answer to that is yes, but we think that's it really to provide a service to our customers, I think we have a slight drill ship fleet. And I think the qualit
componenttext: Yes. No. That's a good question, Sean. I do think that on the larger rill ship fleet, I think the answer to that is yes, but we think that's it really to provide a service to our customers, I think we have a slight drill ship fleet. And I think the quality of our drill ship fleet is second to none. If you actually look at the scope of second-generation assets, which the customer sees and desire, we are certainly one of the largest players in that although nobody have a lot of generation assets. I would say as far as would we be -- would we think that having more ultra-deepwater is ultimately where we should be? Yes, but also we have 3 out of 4 rigs on contracted. We are less likely to go out and add to that number of uncontract assets. And so I think we do agree with that said that it's we just want to be a bit bigger in ultra-deepwater, but also with a we've got 3 uncontracted drill ships, we need to put those to work. And also, we wouldn't want to, I think the quality of the fleet is that important and the feedback we get from our customers is that they see a big distinction between the seventh-generation assets that we have and the earlier in the upcycle sixth-generation assets for a lot of others. I would say that the financial community doesn't make that or a lot in the financial communities think of a drill ship built up to 2009 drill ship, but it certainly not what we hear out of our customers who are more focused on the higher end. And I think you've heard that language out of some of the other drilling as well. Our sales yes, absolutely. It all comes to the quality of the asset and how the market  is volatile. I think there's a good service out there. We're certainly would want to make sure we stay with assets to our customers are really focused on using and stay away from being the cold stacked and perhaps take quite some time to come back.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: That's very helpful. On ARO, honestly, there's some technicality in terms of disclosure. What can you -- what can we glean from what's been discussed as far, give a better sense of how those economics work?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question, and I wish we could just lay it down to the table. I think we would like to do that. But in fairness, our partner is negotiating a lot of the joint ventures and other partnerships. And so to be fair to them, it is -- they don
componenttext: I think it's a good question, and I wish we could just lay it down to the table. I think we would like to do that. But in fairness, our partner is negotiating a lot of the joint ventures and other partnerships. And so to be fair to them, it is -- they don't want to start off with where we agreed after long negotiation as the starting point. I mean, there's just unfair to them to do that. We can't talk it through the framework as far as how the newbuilds higher-priced, and I think some of that is in this document, but -- that was just published today. And it's actually [Section B]indiscernible]  In the back cover of explain how it works. So there's a kind of a page, which we it is document that was just published, just shows that how the framework pricing will work and explain the 8-year contract and the day rate is a function of the cost of the newbuild or undisclosed days plus daily OpEx and overhead costs and the modest escalation. So the framework we have in this recent releases really tried to give a lot more visibility on it. So we didn't want to put this out until it's out premature until the JV -- until ARO Drilling have actually started up. So this morning, we did some announcement this earnings release. We put out this 12, 13-page document. It's not new information, but it is information that is sort of dugout of the quite balloons of documents that we filed in our 10K in February of this year. And it does sort of explain the frame rate. Unfortunately, there is another item. Stephen mentioned, there's a couple of undisclosed items, which -- but -- and you have to make an assumption out that. I would say you have to become assumptions on what those under those are, but I really think that the IR team and Finance team have tried to sort of lay out and give you a lot more help as far as modeling the JV. And when you read through that, I think it will help you. I would say also, but just generally on returns, we are one of the real focuses for myself is allocation of capital and return on capital. And so we're not in the business of investing at this point of the cycle to create poor returns.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would just briefly add that while the return on the newbuilds was obviously a key value driver, we have disclosed the initial rates for the first 3-year contracts for the rigs that were contributed this year, both ARO's and Aramco's as well as the agree
componenttext: I would just briefly add that while the return on the newbuilds was obviously a key value driver, we have disclosed the initial rates for the first 3-year contracts for the rigs that were contributed this year, both ARO's and Aramco's as well as the agreed values of those contributions in total. And those were also some of the key value drivers in the JV.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question, I guess, Mark, your follow up your comment regarding I think you said ultra-deepwater probably may not turn until late 2018 based on your discussions with customers. And I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. Does that suggest that it may
componenttext: A question, I guess, Mark, your follow up your comment regarding I think you said ultra-deepwater probably may not turn until late 2018 based on your discussions with customers. And I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. Does that suggest that it may be more prudent that your idol drillships may not kind of be back to work until probably 2019? Or do you think that there's opportunities that some could go back in the payroll at some point in '18? Just wanted to clarify that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. That's a good question. No, I don't think that at all. We're tracking right now 10 to 12 prospects that we are following very closely. We look at everything around the world, but right now, they're some of these 10 to 12 prospects requiring multiple
componenttext: Sure. That's a good question. No, I don't think that at all. We're tracking right now 10 to 12 prospects that we are following very closely. We look at everything around the world, but right now, they're some of these 10 to 12 prospects requiring multiple rigs. So we're obviously staying very close to what I was trying to get across from my comment was that we don't really see this market, the ultra-deepwater market, bottoming until sometime in the last part of '18. That's all certainly dependent on oil prices if they continue this upward track and move to a position where there's a 6 in front of that number. That's always going to have a profound effect on the ultra-deepwater markets. So right now, we like the way it's trending. We like the fact that we're in a strong commodity environment during the budget approval process right now. This can have a big impact on capital budgets for '18 and '19. So as you know, a lot of the majors. Theybudget out multiple years, so I think this is good timing. The last 2 years, we've had the reverse situation. So -- but right now, we're following 10 to 12 things that we feel that the rigs are definitely suited for and we're going after them. So our goal is to abstain try to get all 4 and contracted before the end of the year. And if things fall in place, that's certainly something we can do before the end of '18.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And my follow up, I guess, for Stephen. The cost guide for next year between 600 and 650, is it right to assume that the low end of that would assume -- I guess I should ask, what's inherent in the bottom end of that guidance? Is it how do we think about
componenttext: And my follow up, I guess, for Stephen. The cost guide for next year between 600 and 650, is it right to assume that the low end of that would assume -- I guess I should ask, what's inherent in the bottom end of that guidance? Is it how do we think about the drillships, idle drillships working at the low end of the guidance?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's a good question, John. I would say that while it seems like a wide range, $15 million, it's really represent a 10% swing overall from high to low. It's a fairly tight range, given we've got only 38% of our available days already contracted for '18. B
componenttext: It's a good question, John. I would say that while it seems like a wide range, $15 million, it's really represent a 10% swing overall from high to low. It's a fairly tight range, given we've got only 38% of our available days already contracted for '18. But obviously, we have some good visibility for [indiscernible] work on a number of rigs. And of course, there's a whole host of different scenarios that could put us within that range, and we get comfortable with that range because we think it encapsulates most of the reasonable utilization scenarios. Now before deepwater utilization will have the largest impact. And, of course, it won't surprise you, given we're in November already the long lead time for work. There's been a fairly likely to have significant idle time in the first half on the floaters. So again, given without really provide revenue guidance, it's probably about as much detail as I can give you on the forecast revenue.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: If I could ask it another way. If we were to assume the drill ships don't work in '18, would the low end of the guidance still be a fair low market?
componenttext: If I could ask it another way. If we were to assume the drill ships don't work in '18, would the low end of the guidance still be a fair low market?

componenttextpreview: No. Yes, I think that we would be below this range if we didn't have any additional floater days. We certainly feel like it's unlikely scenario even though the floater markets challenged today. We do think that it's rigs roll-off and on the global fleet.
componenttext: No. Yes, I think that we would be below this range if we didn't have any additional floater days. We certainly feel like it's unlikely scenario even though the floater markets challenged today. We do think that it's rigs roll-off and on the global fleet. And if there is tenders that are fleets can be very competitive and picking up some of that work. It certainly less likely to impact the first half.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good color. Good color. So maybe just to kick off with the market-related question for Mark. You talked about the dynamics being such that the incremental demand or the demand profile for deepwater rig is less than the contract rollovers. What kind of an
componenttext: Good color. Good color. So maybe just to kick off with the market-related question for Mark. You talked about the dynamics being such that the incremental demand or the demand profile for deepwater rig is less than the contract rollovers. What kind of an balancer what kind of differential are you looking at, Mark, between the rollovers and the demand for rigs in '18 for deepwater?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For '18, I mean, right now, they're -- in the market that we're competing in, with the dual stock 1,250-ton ships, there's 32 of those in the market. There's currently 11 of them available. There's another ship rolling off in '17 and another one in '18. S
componenttext: For '18, I mean, right now, they're -- in the market that we're competing in, with the dual stock 1,250-ton ships, there's 32 of those in the market. There's currently 11 of them available. There's another ship rolling off in '17 and another one in '18. So we're going to be looking at a market somewhere at that point in early '18 of about probably in the 13 to 15 range probably. By the end of the year, if it goes all the way to the end of the year, you're looking at another 8 rigs. It could roll off contract. I mean, you're just seeing backlog erosion that time from the original contracts. But as I've said, we're starting to see more tender activity. I think it's a sign that -- I personally thing that a good sign. That the market is bottoming and the deepwater market is when you see the majors go out for multi-year contracts to try to lock up rigs at lower rates. You're seeing some of that now, but I think you'll continue to see that as we move into '18. But we are tracking 10 to 12 prospects for our ships. I think it's clear in our discussions with operators and have this demand that, that's the preferred ship. With day rates where they are, it just makes a lot of sense whether or not a lower spec ship could do it or not, but difference in cost to the operator. It just makes sense to pick up the higher spec rig having the fleet for multiple years.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

I understand the flow through on equity and earnings. That all makes sense. Stephen, you referenced 2 discrete items. One was transition revenue and the other one was interest income. By mentioning them as discrete items, are those going to flow through direct to Rowan without growing through -- and I look at your presentation too and that's why I'm still asking this question because it's still not clear to me. Whether or not that transitional revenue was going to flow through 100% to Rowan or whether that is just going to be rolled up into that equity earnings component and then come over that one line item over the [indiscernible] ?

componenttext: Those are in addition to the equity line item. We'll have a discrete line item on revenue. We're looking to the transition services. And then in the interest income, well, together, of course, with other interest income-related our cash balance, but it will flow through that line item.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then, Tom, we're not going to leave you out of the circle here. So you guys, you addressed some of the elements around your strategy in the viewpoint of the market. headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think we are in a transition period as far as the global fleet, and so we hit the 20 20. We hit that special 40 years from 1980 when so much of the fleet was built. And so it's sort of when people look back 5, 10 years from now, they'll say, "Well, that
componenttext: I think we are in a transition period as far as the global fleet, and so we hit the 20 20. We hit that special 40 years from 1980 when so much of the fleet was built. And so it's sort of when people look back 5, 10 years from now, they'll say, "Well, that was the time the older fleet the offshore drillers tend to build and have sort of quite intensive build cycles." And so we are going through a difficult period right now, which is sort of a necessary transition between old fleet in the '80s and the new fleet that is built in the sort of the 2005 to 2010 or -- and later. So now having said that, there has been a lot of assets out there. Some of them are going to go away, we've seen that. And some of them will continue to go away. And our customers do have a strong track record from new rigs. And in our marketing operations, we were talking about opportunities. Like when we are marketing and the customers requiring new rigs and our customers will play anything. And more often than not, the answer is that they acquired that new rigs. Now as far as driving attrition, I don't think that M&A will necessarily drive attrition as far as people -- if people got the rig that's basically don't create value, and we believe there is value in these assets. I don't think M&A necessarily does that. What creates attrition is customers know longer wanting particular assets. Having said that, we have historically, we have some. It's hard to say, but I think it's really about good the [indiscernible] is and is fit in the global fleet or even in a particular drillers fleet. I know from Rowan's perspective, we've been very careful about what we've been selling rigs to either scrap them or sell them into local mode. We've done 4 almost all of us. So I don't think M&A necessarily drives attrition. Certainly it doesn't detract from it though.

componenttext: That's a good question, Eduardo. We do sort of think of it from a little bit of a portfolio perspective, although our portfolio is the number of drillships that we have is a lot smaller than some of our competitors. So if you have 15 drillships, you're going to foot some and then you can get the upside later on for the others when you only have 4 and one of one is working, you definitely have to be. But we did consider it in that portfolio. Certainly, those continued value creative in the first one report back to work of the 3 versus the third. We do think about the do believe that will be different. I'd say on short-term job, we actually like the idea of short-term jobs, but we always are cognizant of what is the back of them. Is there an opportunity? So what we don't want to do is ramp up a drillships with all the crews higher the number of people to lower levels as we haven't more of a senior levels already. Get the rig back to work, ramp it up, get everybody fully competent for a very short job and then have to lay everybody off. That is not number of reasons to doing that is because, first of all, it will probably will destroy more value from keeping them stacked. And also, we want to look into a bit more opportunity than that. Having said that, we wouldn't take short-term jobs and we believe a hot rig is more marketable than a one-stack rig, absolutely. And so we evaluated off each opportunity. And frankly, a lot of them is shorter-term jobs that are actually pretty attractive. As long as we figure something on the backend, which frankly today versus 6 months ago, there are more opportunities on the back end. But I think probably other drillers short-term jobs are actually pretty interesting because we feel that the market is going to improve, and therefore, it'd be sort of even better and have some of the best, but we would have some of the best rigs in the world and they would be hot as opposed to one [indiscernible]
