headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Crysta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Rowan Companies' Third Quarter 2017 Earning Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Burke, you
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Crysta, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Rowan Companies' Third Quarter 2017 Earning Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Burke, you may begin.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Welcome to Rowan's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your interest in Rowan. A company of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found on our website at rowan.com. Joining me on the call this mo
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Welcome to Rowan's Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. We appreciate your interest in Rowan. A company of the company's earnings report issued earlier this morning can be found on our website at rowan.com. Joining me on the call this morning are: Tom Burke, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Keller, Executive Vice President, Business Development; and Stephen Butz, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I'd like to remind you that expectations expressed during this conference call are forward-looking statements and are subject to risks, assumptions, trends and uncertainties such as market conditions and the general economy, commodity prices, offshore drilling activity levels, renegotiations, early termination or cancellation of contracts, risks related to our joint venture with Saudi Aramco and other risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially. Please refer to our earnings release and SEC filings on our website that more fully describe forward-looking statements, risk factors and other events that could impact future results. 
Please note that information discussed during today's call is as of now and may be outdated at the time of any replay. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom Burke, Rowan's President and Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter 2017 earnings call. We appreciate your participation today and your continued interest and investment in Rowan. Following my prepared remarks, Mark will give you an update on the offshore
componenttext:
Thank you, Carrie. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter 2017 earnings call. We appreciate your participation today and your continued interest and investment in Rowan. 
Following my prepared remarks, Mark will give you an update on the offshore drilling market, and Stephen will walk you through our financial performance and guidance. And then I'll conclude with some thoughts on ARO Drilling before opening the call to questions. 
In the third quarter, we believe Permian crude oil prices continue to help the offshore rig market find the bottom and even make some modest improvements in some categories and regions. Interest from our customers to resume exploration drilling seems to be increasing. However, the majority of the visible demand continues to be for shorter cycle activities and mature basins. While this dynamic is supported on a gradual recovery in jack-up activity, the Deepwater floater market is much more dependent on demand from exploration drilling. Though we've seen a general increase in tendering activity in the floater market over the past quarters, we still believe incremental contract fixtures will struggle to keep pace with the cadence of contracts from rolling off through the end of 2017 and well into 2018. Regardless of the market segment, as contracts that was signed before the downturn come to an end, we have already seen a strong trend for all the rigs to be replaced by modern, more capable rigs. We expect this trend to continue, especially in the floater market where there is a strong technical differentiation in the latest generation of rigs. 
As we approach the end of the year, crude oil prices will play a vital role in E&P budget and project approvals for 2018. Mark will go through in more detail about our recent contract awards, utilization trends and our outlook for the Rowan fleet. 
This quarter end, we announced the launch of ARO Drilling as joint venture with Saudi Aramco. I'd like to take a moment to thank and congratulate our employees on both the Saudi Aramco to work tirelessly to ensure successful startup to ARO Drilling. It's been almost a year since we announced the signing of this historic partnership with the largest jack-up customer in the world, and we're pleased to see it fully operating. I'll go into more detail about ARO Drilling following Stephen's comments. 
This morning, we reported a net loss of $0.17 per diluted share in the third quarter from a loss of 23% per diluted share in the previous quarter. Our third quarter adjusted EBITDA was $99 million versus the consensus estimate of approximately $83 million. We are pleased that J.P. Bussell and Rowan Norway went back to work during the quarter, improving our total jack-up utilization of 78%. 
Our impressive operational efficiency continues in the third quarter with approximately 99% up-time fleet-wide and exhibited ongoing capital spending discipline and control of cost, which resulted in a cash balance at quarter end of approximately $1.2 billion and a cash balance today of over $1.3 billion. As we consider capital allocation opportunities, we're mindful of maintaining an attractive credit profile and a strong solid balance sheet. We recognize the value in preserving liquidity. And when we examine opportunistic investments, we believe the transactions should be strategic, accretive and not pollute the asset quality of our fleet. 
Now for a more detailed look at the market, I'll hand the call over to Mark.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, we were pleased with the overall improvement in market cinema as well as the backlog additions for our jack-up fleet, most notably in Trinidad. As announced in our most recent fleet status
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. During the third quarter, we were pleased with the overall improvement in market cinema as well as the backlog additions for our jack-up fleet, most notably in Trinidad. As announced in our most recent fleet status report, we extended our current contracts with BP on both the Joe Douglas and the EXL II. These commitments had approximately 1 year of work for each unit. Additionally, the Ralph Coffman also secured a contract extension, which will carry the rig through the end of the year. Our excellence in operational performance in the region continues to lead to repeat business with valued customers. 
Also this quarter, Shell contracted the Gorilla VI forge program in Trinidad. The jack-up were mobilized from the North Sea for 150-day drilling program that is scheduled to commence in the second quarter 2018. There are 4 priced options following the initial program, which, if exercised, would keep the rig busy until early 2019. 
As a reminder, the Gorilla VI continues to receive day rate until early March as part of the termination agreement with ConocoPhillips. The worldwide demand for harsh environment jack-ups is showing signs of health and utilization is hovering around levels that are supportive for improved commercial terms. Although demand in this subsector is improving, I should note that around half of the projects for these more capable units originates from benign environment regions with operators being attracted to the generally higher levels of efficiency that these harsh environment rig provide. The overall jack-up demand appears to have bottomed. The supply-demand balance for benign environment jack-ups continues to be extremely challenging with day rates approximating operating costs in some regions.
With the plentiful supply of modern rigs that will warm our hot stack, combined with substantial queue of newbuilds, it is difficult to predict when the promotional environment will improve on a global basis. This appreciation for the distinction between harsh and benign environment jack-ups is supportive of Rowan's strategy and mission statement: To be recognized by our customers as a sufficient and capable provider of demand and contract drilling services. 85% of our marketed jack-ups are high-spec with most rigs also being ready for harsh environments. Today and historically, utilization levels are higher for this caliber of rig. 
Now looking at specific jack-up regions of the world. Middle East provides significant potential for increase in demand for 2018 considering outstanding tender requirements across the region. Incremental demand is anticipated from Saudi Aramco, National Drilling Company, Kuwait Oil Co. and KJO, among other customers. EXL I and EXL IV currently tendered on multiple projects in the region, and we are hopeful to secure contract for those units over the coming quarters. 
The Bob Palmer is currently contracted to Saudi Aramco until the end of the year. Discussions are ongoing about a possible extension for this high-spec jack-up to be leased into ARO and continue its successful track record of deep gas drilling. 
The North Sea. 5 of our 6 jack-ups are currently contracted as Rowan Norway recently completed a project in the U.K. with Repsol Sinopec. We are looking at multiple opportunities for the Rowan Norway and the Gorilla VII, both in and out of the region for projects starting in 2018. 
In the U.S. Gulf of Mexico, we secured a new contract with [indiscernible] Offshore for the EXL III. But the region remains one of the weakest jack-up regions in the world. The conversations with customers have picked up slightly now that hurricane season is behind us, but continuous work may be a challenge in this market so the EXL III is also being tendered worldwide. 
Now turning to the floater market. I'd like to briefly mention recent news in Latin America before focusing on the ultra-deepwater market. We continue to actively participate in opportunities in Latin America and closely monitor the ongoing bid rounds. Last week, the high interest from IOCs in the Brazilian bidding rounds further strengthened our view that this region will have an increase in activity level in the coming years. 
In Mexico, the next round of watch will be in January of 2018, which should have closed to 30 deepwater blocks up for bid. 
In the broad floater market, we don't expect contracted demand to make a definitive turn until at least late 2018. There's a lack of near-term incremental projects in the face of significant continued contract roll-offs in the coming months. 
Though fixtures are few and far between, recent contract awards support that well-equipped seventh-generation units are preferred by customers, and we are actively pursuing approximately 10 to 12 prospects for our drillships. 
Programs range in link from 150 days to 3 years, and commencement dates are expected during the next 12 to 18 months. There are only 18 build stack, 1,250-ton capable units available before the end of 2018, so that niche market could tighten up well in advance of the total fleet. 
As I cautioned on the last call, continued commodity price strength for the remainder of the year will play a key role in a follow-through of plan 2018 and 2019 deepwater activity. Rowan is well-positioned in the current stage of the market with high-performing shallow water assets and 4 the most capable ultra-deepwater drillships in the industry today. We are exhibiting operational excellence acutely focused on adding backlog and strategically prepared for the recovery. 
This concludes my remarks. And I will now turn the call over to Stephen.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. In addition to reviewing our third quarter 2017 results today, I'll provide you with updates on our cost and capital spending guidance for the remainder of 2017 and provide preliminary guidance for 2018. Follow
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. In addition to reviewing our third quarter 2017 results today, I'll provide you with updates on our cost and capital spending guidance for the remainder of 2017 and provide preliminary guidance for 2018. Following my comments, I'll turn the call back over to Tom. 
As Tom mentioned, we are pleased with the recent launch of ARO Drilling. Shortly following the close of the third quarter, we received an $88 million cash distribution from ARO as part of the formation process, further bolstering our liquidity in this challenging market. Our cash balance is now over $1.3 billion. Together with our $1.5 billion revolving credit facility, this strong liquidity positions us very well to both weather the storm and make opportunistic investments. 
Now for our quarterly results. This morning, we reported a net loss of $21 million or $0.17 per diluted share in comparison to a net loss of $29 million or $0.23 per diluted share last quarter. Both quarters included minor impacts from the early extinguishment of debt with the third quarter including a $500,000 loss and the second quarter including a $2.4 million gain. 
The quarter-over-quarter reduction in our net loss per share was driven by an income tax benefit related to a lapse in the statute of limitations. 
Revenue for the third quarter was $289 million, excluding rebillable items, a decrease of 9% from the prior quarter due to the declining deepwater revenue. Despite the overall reduction, we were pleased to see a $6 million improvement in jack-up revenue attributed to the start-up of the J.P. Bussell in the Middle East and the Rowan Norway in the U.K. 
Operating costs remained relatively flat quarter-over-quarter, so our adjusted EBITDA declined to $99 million from $131 million in the second quarter of 2017, while our EBITDA margins declined to 34%. While this is now well off recent peak levels, I would add that I'm pleased that we've been able to maintain an EBITDA margin 3 years into the cyclical downturn that is equal to our EBITDA margin from the first quarter of 2014. 
Our quarterly jack-up utilization increased to 78%, up 6% from the second quarter level, though average day rates decreased slightly. Our third quarter deepwater utilization was 50%, considering the revenue-producing days on the Rowan Reliance, where we are recognizing deferred revenue related to the Cobalt prepayment and termination in 2016. Notably, our Rowan Resolute ultra-deepwater drillship, once again, did not incur any unbillable downtime during this third quarter. A [indiscernible] has now accomplished for 5 consecutive quarters. Our total operational downtime, including both the floater and jack-up fleet, was only 1%. 
Now turning to expenses. Operating costs for the third quarter were $165 million, net of rebillable item, in line with low end of our guidance and flat with the second quarter level. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect operating costs to decline to $150 million to $160 million. The expected decline is largely due to the launch of ARO Drilling and the associated sale of assets to ARO. As a reminder, this guidance excludes rebillables as well as certain potential ARO Drilling pass-through cost that we expect to have an equal offset in revenue. 
SG&A expenses for the third quarter totaled $25 million, representing a slight increase from $22 million in the second quarter, but they were at the low end of our guidance. As we mentioned in our prior call, second quarter G&A expense benefited from a reduced stock price and its impact on certain compensation awards that are mark-to-market. We anticipate our fourth quarter SG&A expense will remain relatively flat with the third quarter level. 
For the third quarter, depreciation expense totaled $103 million, and we expect full year expense of slightly higher than $400 million, just above our previous guidance due to the delayed sale of rigs to ARO Drilling. Interest expense for the third quarter was $39 million, and our 2017 estimate is $156 million. 
Our full year guidance for income tax expense has been reduced to the mid-$20 million range compared to our prior guidance of the low $40 million, primarily due to a tax benefit as a result of the resolution of our prior year tax contingency. Income tax expense will likely continue to remain volatile for the foreseeable future, and tax expense will be impacted not only by levels of pretax income, but also by the timing of contract awards, changes in valuation allowance on deferred tax assets and various other factors. We continue to expect our cash tax payments during 2017 to total in the mid-$30 million range. 
Now let's discuss our cash flow and balance sheet. Capital expenditures totaled $21 million in the third quarter, $5 million below second quarter levels. We are reducing our full year guidance from $120 million to $130 million down to $120 million. We ended the quarter with just above $1.2 billion in cash before the ARO distribution. 
As previously stated, we retired $7 million of debt in the third quarter, which brings our year-to-date total debt retirement to $170 million. 
Next, I would like to provide full year guidance for 2018, keeping in mind that we are currently on our budget process, and these estimates will be refined on our next quarterly earnings call. As I mentioned last quarter, Rowan will be reimbursed by ARO Drilling for back office and operations support costs, which we will recognize as revenue as part of the transition services arrangement. 
For 2018, we expect transition services revenue to approximate $30 million, but to gradually decline thereafter over the next few years until there are no remaining transition services. Our 2018 operating expenses, excluding rebillable items, are expected to range from $600 million to $650 million. These estimates could change depending on the schedule of drilling units returning to work. 
SG&A expense for 2018 is estimated to range from $95 million to $105 million, fairly in line with the 2017 level. 
Depreciation expense is expected to range from $370 million to $380 million, and interest expense is forecast at $155 million in 2018. 
As most of our contributions to ARO were structured as shareholder loans, we also expect to generate approximately $10 million of interest income from ARO Drilling on top of interest income related to our cash balance. And finally, we estimate our maintenance capital expenditures will total less than $100 million in 2018. 
As a reminder, we are accounting for ARO Drilling under the equity method. However, we also intend to provide supplementary financial details in our earnings releases and periodic filings going forward. To assist you with your forecasting of ARO, we have disclosed the day rates on the initial 5 rigs, which ARO will collect as revenue and assume the operating costs forward. We have also disclosed the transition services cost for ARO to be paid to Rowan. 
Lastly, ARO Drilling has assumed the cost of our former Saudi Arabian shorebase. 
Now before opening the call for questions and answers, I'm going to hand the call back to Tom for some brief closing remarks.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Stephen. In closing, we are excited about the launch of ARO Drilling and strongly believe that this venture will be a significant long-term growth driver for our company. The $88 million cash distribution we received in October, together with the
componenttext:
Thanks, Stephen. In closing, we are excited about the launch of ARO Drilling and strongly believe that this venture will be a significant long-term growth driver for our company. The $88 million cash distribution we received in October, together with the second and larger distribution expected in late 2018 after we sell the Scooter Yeargain and the Hank Boswell, are examples of the immediate benefits created by this joint venture. 
However, we believe the most significant value creation from the JV is still ahead of us and will become more apparent once the newbuild rigs enter the ARO Drilling fleet. This morning, we published an appendix to our investor presentation outlining the various components of ARO drilling. We hope this summary will help to clarify the structure and clearly illustrate the long-term value creation that we believe ARO Drilling will provide to Rowan. We believe the visible growth of ARO Drilling is a major differentiator for us in an industry that currently struggles to have much visibility and stability. 
Operator, we're now ready to turn the call over for questions.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: You've been linked in the press with some M&A speculation, and I want to ask you to comment on that directly. But given the bifurcation that we're seeing between harsh environment assets, both from the jack-up side and the floater side, I wonder what your
componenttext: You've been linked in the press with some M&A speculation, and I want to ask you to comment on that directly. But given the bifurcation that we're seeing between harsh environment assets, both from the jack-up side and the floater side, I wonder what your view is on the durability of that trend. Whether it's sort of transient with regard to your we are in the cycle for this year and maybe the next 1 or 2 years. Or if it's sufficiently structural that M&A that focuses on harsh environment jack-ups is going to be more of a priority for Rowan. So sort of double down on that fleet profile that you built today, at least from the jack-up side.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good question. So with respect to M&A, it's obviously hard to make specific comments. And one of my -- one of our competitors has a comment that he'd been bought and sold so many times, and nothing ever happened. So with that said, and what Rowan has
componenttext: Yes. Good question. So with respect to M&A, it's obviously hard to make specific comments. And one of my -- one of our competitors has a comment that he'd been bought and sold so many times, and nothing ever happened. So with that said, and what Rowan has said and what we've [indiscernible] as far as our perspective on M&A that we should definitely look at all transactions as being a strategic, accretive and shouldn't validate the asset quality of our fleet. And that's been our -- there was a lot of haggle either about how we think about individual asset transactions and how we think about our larger transactions. I would say that one underlying sort of focus on that is our desire, our strong desire, to improve the return on invested capital and make sure that, from a capital allocation perspective, every dollar that we invest in new assets is well-spent. So we are certainly focused on them. With respect to your specific question about the harsh environments in the jack-up market, clearly, that has been our thing -- our focus for the last several years. We obviously have moved into the ultra-deepwater at the high end, but the Skeie transaction that we did in -- that we executed in 2010 was aligned with entering that market. I do think the harsh environment market is, as we think about the whole of jack-up market, it is a big market. And the harsh environment market is a small part of it, and it's definitely somewhere that Rowan need to be focused historically and something that we would -- definitely, it's somewhere where we like. Now the problem is with those assets, there aren't that many compared to the large number of assets that are out there in the jack-up space. But there are some jack-ups -- harsh environment jack-ups in the Chinese shipyards as well. So there are some opportunities out there, but we continue to view that as an interesting market, as we always have the last 5 or 6 years.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: All right. I appreciate that perspective. And just for my follow-up, is there any update with the jack-ups in Brazil that you've -- that are on an auction? That seems to be radio silent. But have you heard anything back from that [indiscernible]?
componenttext: All right. I appreciate that perspective. And just for my follow-up, is there any update with the jack-ups in Brazil that you've -- that are on an auction? That seems to be radio silent. But have you heard anything back from that [indiscernible]?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have a good dialogue with Petrobras. And they are going through their processes. It is -- as I said, it is made one way or the other, from our perspective or from their perspective. We'll certainly let -- we'll certainly put out release on that. B
componenttext: Yes. We have a good dialogue with Petrobras. And they are going through their processes. It is -- as I said, it is made one way or the other, from our perspective or from their perspective. We'll certainly let -- we'll certainly put out release on that. But it is -- we do find those assets attractive. And as you can see now, I was at LeTourneau where we built those assets. So I feel like we've got a good understanding of those rigs. I mean, no rig is perfect. That's for sure. Unless they happen to be a Rowan drillship. But no rig is perfect. But we like those assets. We know them -- I know very well, and I spent a year of my life closely involved in that project. So we're excited about it, but we have certainly -- certainly, having a good correspondence with Petrobras on that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Haithum Nokta from Clarksons Platou.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Haithum Nokta from Clarksons Platou.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Congrats on closing the ARO transaction and commencing operations. I wanted to ask -- at the start, going through the presentation, I think, just hit. But can you give us maybe just a sneak of what kind of level of disclosure you expect from the financial
componenttext: Congrats on closing the ARO transaction and commencing operations. I wanted to ask -- at the start, going through the presentation, I think, just hit. But can you give us maybe just a sneak of what kind of level of disclosure you expect from the financial side? Going forward, is it going to be more than just the equity income line item? Will there be like an income statement and balance sheet? Or will this be kind of house-select financial data?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, Haithum. Glad to answer that question. We will have, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, supplementary financial details, both in our earnings release and our Qs and Ks going forward. And initially, it will likely include some summary balance sh
componenttext: Sure, Haithum. Glad to answer that question. We will have, as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, supplementary financial details, both in our earnings release and our Qs and Ks going forward. And initially, it will likely include some summary balance sheet data as well as many of the -- our key line items from the income statement. It will also be subject to a significance test. And when it reaches a certain level of significance, it will be -- will have to be required to provide the audited financials of ARO. So obviously, we expect this joint venture to grow dramatically. And of course, as you know, our expected results for '18 and '19 are relatively weak. So it could hit that -- those levels where audits are required fairly early. So I think that -- in summary, I think there will be a lot of transparency around the results.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just from a disclosure standpoint, would you expect that a lot of the details that have been redacted in the shareholders agreement, will those kind of just come out over time through the financials, most likely, as opposed to more expl
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just from a disclosure standpoint, would you expect that a lot of the details that have been redacted in the shareholders agreement, will those kind of just come out over time through the financials, most likely, as opposed to more explicit updates?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean, to be clear, there weren't that many items that were redacted. It would simply be the discount to market on the index rate, which, of course, we did disclose the results for on those, and the return on the newbuild rigs. But really, oth
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean, to be clear, there weren't that many items that were redacted. It would simply be the discount to market on the index rate, which, of course, we did disclose the results for on those, and the return on the newbuild rigs. But really, otherwise, most of the details are already out there. So of course, those items will be visible in the financial results of ARO. Now I've realized, the newbuilds won't be -- first, newbuild won't be coming out until 2021. But of course, certain details will probably be required in the footnotes to the financial statement. So obviously, we haven't worked through all of that yet at this point.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And I just wanted to ask on the back of, I guess, Mark's comment that you're seeing a lot more demand for harsh environment jack-ups in nonharsh environment areas. Are there -- I mean, obviously, the Gorilla VI is an example of that. But is t
componenttext: Fair enough. And I just wanted to ask on the back of, I guess, Mark's comment that you're seeing a lot more demand for harsh environment jack-ups in nonharsh environment areas. Are there -- I mean, obviously, the Gorilla VI is an example of that. But is that -- I mean, is that really kind of a broad trend you're starting to see? And are there certain regions where this makes sense more than other areas? Or it's just kind of, you can get a big beefy rig for a lower cost than you could have ever pour?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. It depends on a regional basis, but we've seen those rigs now where they're approaching 85% utilization, which is where the market, historically, you're able to raise rates. And so we decided that seeing some of the demand outside of the North Sea, w
componenttext: Yes. It depends on a regional basis, but we've seen those rigs now where they're approaching 85% utilization, which is where the market, historically, you're able to raise rates. And so we decided that seeing some of the demand outside of the North Sea, we thought we could take some of the supply into the North Sea and maybe help that situation a little bit in the North Sea from a day rate standpoint. But we are seeing stuff in West Africa, Middle East, Trinidad, certainly, for those type of rigs. There's stuff in the Gulf of Mexico, Mexico. So we're monitoring every market. A lot of people thought we were crazy when the first time Tom and I said we were taking the Bob Palmer to the Middle East to market in about 30 feet water. So there are opportunities as wellbores get more difficult to drill. They like the operating capability of those rigs doing -- drilling this deep extended rich wells.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gregory Lewis from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gregory Lewis from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the closing of the ARO JV. Could you talk a little bit about it? I know in the past that there's been a potential for ARO to maybe grow a little bit faster than what is stated. So as we look at ARO today, based on what you played down on the p
componenttext: Congrats on the closing of the ARO JV. Could you talk a little bit about it? I know in the past that there's been a potential for ARO to maybe grow a little bit faster than what is stated. So as we look at ARO today, based on what you played down on the presentation, it looks like it's just kind of plug-and-play. The cash is just going to build up over time as you fund the newbuilds. Is there any way, just looking at the overall market in Saudi Arabia, where we could see opportunities for ARO to take advantage of where asset prices are today and maybe, I guess, accelerate their share?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. Greg, it's a good question, and it's something we actually spent quite a bit of time on. So I think -- I'm on the Board of ARO, but I can't speak for ARO. But I would say, just anecdotally, I think it would be unlikely for ARO to buy these rigs becau
componenttext: Yes. Greg, it's a good question, and it's something we actually spent quite a bit of time on. So I think -- I'm on the Board of ARO, but I can't speak for ARO. But I would say, just anecdotally, I think it would be unlikely for ARO to buy these rigs because it has a significant opportunity in front of it as far as the newbuild programs. So it would be less likely to buy rigs that aren't part of its newbuild program. Having said that, they -- it does seem, as per Mark's comments, that there is an opportunity for incremental demand in Saudi Arabia. We believe that ARO [indiscernible] addition to that. Obviously, we are -- we have some uncontracted assets, but not that many. And we do believe that if there is incremental demand in the Saudi Arabia as long as ARO is competitive on price and it has the right operational performance, we think that we have an opportunity to grow its fleet over the next several years, even before the newbuilds program starts in Saudi Arabia through the maritime JV that is just about up and running or is up and running right now.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just because it's been out in the market as Borr formed its partnership with Schlumberger. Just as you think about that, I mean, it sounds like there could be other opportunities for similar type of relationships like that with Borr.
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just because it's been out in the market as Borr formed its partnership with Schlumberger. Just as you think about that, I mean, it sounds like there could be other opportunities for similar type of relationships like that with Borr. I mean, as you look at your drill -- as you look at your floaters, I mean, you have 3 idle floaters. As you think about trying to coddle together or find work for those rigs, I mean, are you having discussions about maybe forming partnerships with other service providers to maybe give you a leg-up and then trying to find that incremental contract for some of those floaters?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that probably most of those conversations are more directed at the jack-up markets and more. But having said that, I think there is an interest depending on the customer on that kind of packaging. I would say as far as an alliance with se
componenttext: Yes. I would say that probably most of those conversations are more directed at the jack-up markets and more. But having said that, I think there is an interest depending on the customer on that kind of packaging. I would say as far as an alliance with service companies, it's something we do talk a lot about. I have had a lot of discussions with various service companies, including Schlumberger. And I mean, clearly, I can't talk Schlumberger, but they -- I think they've made it pretty clear that they are not exclusive with Borr Drilling. And also, yes, most of the release is about alliances. All that particular alliances definitely come from one side and not the other. So as we've said, we are talking across all of the service companies about how to change the business model, how to basically help our customers reduce their overall cost while still becoming more efficient and then driving opportunities across the board with various service companies, including Schlumberger. So I think it is -- there's a lot of discussion on it. Not that much has actually happened yet, but I think there's an interest on -- in these parties.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Meakim from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sean Meakim from JPMorgan.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: So maybe just a follow-up on the M&A topic. Some of the recent press reports we've seen and, of course, some of your peers have announced some deals. So I just thought maybe it is worth asking the question. Do you find a larger drillship fleet as attracti
componenttext: So maybe just a follow-up on the M&A topic. Some of the recent press reports we've seen and, of course, some of your peers have announced some deals. So I just thought maybe it is worth asking the question. Do you find a larger drillship fleet as attractive as a potential outcome through the cycle? And at some point, would you also maybe consider semis as part of a larger fleet, particularly in the North Sea?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. No. That's a good question, Sean. Thank you for that. I do think that on the larger drillship fleet, I think the answer to that is yes, but we think that to really -- to be -- to provide a service to our customers, I think we are -- we have a medium
componenttext: Yes. No. That's a good question, Sean. Thank you for that. I do think that on the larger drillship fleet, I think the answer to that is yes, but we think that to really -- to be -- to provide a service to our customers, I think we are -- we have a medium of [ slide ] drillship fleet. And I think the quality of our drillship fleet is second to none. If you actually look at who's got the seventh-generation assets, which the customer sees and desire, we are certainly one of the largest players in that. Although nobody has a lot of seventh-generation assets. I would say as far as would we be -- do we think that having more ultra-deepwater is ultimately where we should be? Yes. But also, we have 3 out of 4 rigs uncontracted. We are less likely to go out and add to that number of uncontracted assets. And so I think we do agree with the thesis that we need to probably be a bit bigger in ultra-deepwater. But we definitely -- when you've got 3 uncontracted drillships, we need to -- you need to put those to work. And also, we wouldn't want to -- I think -- we think the quality of the fleet is very important. And the feedback we get from our customers is that they see a big distinction between the seventh-generation assets that we have and the earlier in the upcycled sixth-generation assets that a lot of others have. I would say that the financial community doesn't make that distinction. Or a lot in the financial community just think that a drillship built after 2009 is a drillship, but it's certainly not what we hear out of our customers who are more focused on the higher end. And I think you've heard that language out of some of the other drillers as well. I'd say on semis, yes, absolutely. It all comes to the quality of the asset and how market is volatile. I think there's a lot of good semis out there. We're certainly would want to make sure we stay with the assets that our customers are really focused on using and stay away from things that will be cold-stacked and perhaps take quite some time to come back. Did that answer your question?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. No. Very helpful. Yes, all the details are very helpful, Tom. On ARO, understanding that there is some sensitivity in terms of disclosure, but can you walk us through maybe the framework or some of the economics embedded in the payback assumptions on
componenttext: Yes. No. Very helpful. Yes, all the details are very helpful, Tom. On ARO, understanding that there is some sensitivity in terms of disclosure, but can you walk us through maybe the framework or some of the economics embedded in the payback assumptions on the newbuild contracts? Just trying to -- what can you -- what can we glean from what's been disclosed so far to kind of get a better sense of how those economics work?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think you can -- it's a good question, and I wish we could just lay it down to the table. I think we would like to do that. But in fairness, our partner is negotiating a lot about the joint venture and other partnerships. And so to be fair to them, it i
componenttext: I think you can -- it's a good question, and I wish we could just lay it down to the table. I think we would like to do that. But in fairness, our partner is negotiating a lot about the joint venture and other partnerships. And so to be fair to them, it is -- they don't want to start off with where we agreed after a long negotiation as the starting point. I mean, that'd be just unfair -- it's unfair to them to do that. We can't talk you through the framework as far as how the newbuilds are priced. And I think some of that is in this document, but -- that we just published today. And it's actually Section E at the back that kind of explains how it works. So there's a kind of a page which we -- in this document that we've just published, it just shows that -- shows how the framework for pricing will work and explains the 8-year contract and the day rate as a function of the cost of the newbuild over undisclosed days plus daily OpEx and overhead costs and a modest escalation. So the framework we have in this recent release just really tried to give a lot more visibility on it. And we didn't want to put this out until -- it felt premature until the JV -- until ARO Drilling have actually started up. So this morning, we did some announcements. This earnings release, we put out this 12-, 13-page document. It's not new information, but it is information that is sort of dug out of the quite voluminous documents that we filed in our 10K in February of this year. And it does sort of explain the frame rate. Unfortunately, there is another item. Just as Stephen mentioned, there's a couple of undisclosed items, which we'll -- but it's -- and you will have to make an assumption of that. I would say, you have to make an assumption on what those -- under those slide absence are. But I really think that the IR team and the Finance team have tried to sort of lay out and give you a lot more help as far as modeling the JV. And when you read through that, I think it will help you. I would say also, but just generally on returns, we are -- one of the real focuses for myself is allocation of capital and return on capital. And so we're not in the business of investing at this point in the cycle to create poor returns.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I would just briefly add that while the return on the newbuilds was obviously a key value driver, we have disclosed the initial rates for the first 3-year contracts for the rigs that were contributed this year, both ARO's and Aramco's, as well as
componenttext: Yes. And I would just briefly add that while the return on the newbuilds was obviously a key value driver, we have disclosed the initial rates for the first 3-year contracts for the rigs that were contributed this year, both ARO's and Aramco's, as well as the agreed values of those contributions in total. And those were also some of the key value drivers in the JV.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jud Bailey from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jud Bailey from Wells Fargo.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question, I guess, Mark, your -- following up on your comment regarding -- I think you said ultra-deepwater probably may not turn until late 2018 based on your discussions with customers. And I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. Does that suggest
componenttext: A question, I guess, Mark, your -- following up on your comment regarding -- I think you said ultra-deepwater probably may not turn until late 2018 based on your discussions with customers. And I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. Does that suggest that it may be more prudent that your idle drillships may not kind of be back to work until probably 2019? Or do you think that there's opportunities that some could go back in the payroll at some point in '18? Just wanted to clarify that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a good question, Jud. No, I don't think that at all. We're tracking right now 10 to 12 prospects that we are following very closely. We look at everything around the world. But right now, they're -- some of these 10 to 12 prospects are requirin
componenttext: Sure. It's a good question, Jud. No, I don't think that at all. We're tracking right now 10 to 12 prospects that we are following very closely. We look at everything around the world. But right now, they're -- some of these 10 to 12 prospects are requiring multiple rigs. So we're obviously staying very close to them. What I was trying to get across from my comments was that we don't really see this market, the ultra-deepwater market, bottoming until some time in the last part of '18. They're -- that's all certainly dependent on oil prices. If they continue this upward track and move to a position where there's a 6 in front of that number, that's always going to have a profound effect on the ultra-deepwater market. So right now, we like the way it's trending. We like the fact that we're in a strong commodity environment during the budget approval process right now. That's going to have a big impact on capital budgets for '18 and '19. So as you know, a lot of the majors, they budget out multiple years. So I think this is good timing. The last 2 years, we've had the reverse situation. So -- but right now, we're -- Jud, we're following 10 to 12 things that we feel like our rigs are definitely suited for, and we're going after them. So our goal is to obviously try to get all 4 of them contracted before the end of the year. And I think if things fall in place, that's certainly something we can do before the end of '18.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And my follow up, I guess, for Stephen. The cost guide for next year between $600 million and $650 million, is it right to assume that the low end of that would assume -- I guess I should ask, what's inherent in the bottom end of that gui
componenttext: Okay. All right. And my follow up, I guess, for Stephen. The cost guide for next year between $600 million and $650 million, is it right to assume that the low end of that would assume -- I guess I should ask, what's inherent in the bottom end of that guidance? Is it -- how do we think about the drillships, idle drillships, working at the low end of the guidance?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And it's a good question, Jud. I would say that the -- while it seems like a wide range, $50 million, it really only represents a 10% swing overall from high to low. So we feel it's a fairly tight range, given we've got only 38% of our available days alre
componenttext: And it's a good question, Jud. I would say that the -- while it seems like a wide range, $50 million, it really only represents a 10% swing overall from high to low. So we feel it's a fairly tight range, given we've got only 38% of our available days already contracted for '18. But obviously, we have some good visibility for follow-on work on a number of rigs. Of course, there's a whole host of different scenarios that could put us within that range. And we get comfortable with that range because we think it encapsulates most of the reasonable utilization scenarios. Now deepwater utilization will have the largest impact. And of course, that won't surprise you given we're in November already, a long lead time for work, that it's -- we're fairly likely to have significant idle time in the first half on the floaters. So I mean, again, given we don't really providing revenue guidance, it's probably about as much detail as I can give you on our forecast on revenue.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess if I could try to ask it another way. If we were to assume that the drillships don't work in '18, would the low end of the guidance still be a fair low mark?
componenttext: Okay. I guess if I could try to ask it another way. If we were to assume that the drillships don't work in '18, would the low end of the guidance still be a fair low mark?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: No. I -- yes, I think that we would be below this range if we didn't have any additional floater days. We certainly feel like that's an unlikely scenario. Even though the floater market's challenged today, it -- we do think that it's rigs roll-off and on
componenttext: No. I -- yes, I think that we would be below this range if we didn't have any additional floater days. We certainly feel like that's an unlikely scenario. Even though the floater market's challenged today, it -- we do think that it's rigs roll-off and on the global fleet. And if there's tenders, that our fleets can be very competitive in picking up some of that work. But it's certainly less likely to impact the first half.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Kurt Hallead from RBC.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Kurt Hallead from RBC.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good color. Good color. So maybe just to kick off with a market-related question for Mark. You talked about the dynamics being such that the incremental demand or the demand profile for deepwater rig is less than the contract rollovers. What kind of end b
componenttext: Good color. Good color. So maybe just to kick off with a market-related question for Mark. You talked about the dynamics being such that the incremental demand or the demand profile for deepwater rig is less than the contract rollovers. What kind of end balancer, what kind of differential are you looking at, Mark, between the rollovers and the demand for rigs in '18 for deepwater?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: For '18, I mean, you're -- right now, there are -- in the market that we're competing in with the dual stack 1,250-ton ships, there's 32 of those in the market. There's currently 11 of them available. There's another ship rolling off in '17 and another on
componenttext: For '18, I mean, you're -- right now, there are -- in the market that we're competing in with the dual stack 1,250-ton ships, there's 32 of those in the market. There's currently 11 of them available. There's another ship rolling off in '17 and another one in '18. So we're going to be looking at a market somewhere at that point in early '18 of about probably in the 13 to 15 range, probably. By the end of the year, if it goes all the way to the end of the year, you're looking at another 8 rigs. It could roll off contract. I mean, you're just seeing backlog erosion big time from the regional contracts. But as I've said, though, Kurt, I mean, we're starting to see more tender activity, I think, is a sign that -- I personally think that a good sign that the market is bottoming. And deepwater market is when you see the majors go out for multiyear contracts to try to lock up rigs at lower rates. You're seeing some of that now, but I think you'll continue to see that as we move into '18. And -- but we are tracking 10 to 12 prospects for our ships. I think it's clear in our discussions with operators that have this demand that, that's the preferred ship. With day rates, where they are, it just makes a lot of sense whether or not a lower-spec ship could do it or not. But you look at the difference in cost to the operator, it just makes sense to pick up the higher-spec rig and having your fleet for multiple years.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it. Okay. And does the -- maybe a follow-up on the ARO JV, just to make sure that I'm a little bit clear on the dynamic. I understand the equity method. I understand the flow-through on equity and earnings. That all makes sense. Stephen, you r
componenttext: Got it. Got it. Okay. And does the -- maybe a follow-up on the ARO JV, just to make sure that I'm a little bit clear on the dynamic. I understand the equity method. I understand the flow-through on equity and earnings. That all makes sense. Stephen, you referenced 2 discrete items. One was transition revenue and the other one was interest income. By mentioning them as discrete items, are those going to flow through direct to Rowan without going through -- and I look at your presentation, too, and that's why I'm still asking this question because it's still not clear to me. Whether or not that transition revenue was going to flow through 100% to Rowan or whether that's just going to be rolled up into that equity earnings component and then come over in that one line item over to [indiscernible].

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: So those are in addition to the equity line item. We'll have a discrete line item on revenue. We're looking to the transition services. And then in the interest income will be together, of course, with other interest income related to our cash balance. Bu
componenttext: So those are in addition to the equity line item. We'll have a discrete line item on revenue. We're looking to the transition services. And then in the interest income will be together, of course, with other interest income related to our cash balance. But it will flow through that line item.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then Tom, I'm not going to leave you out of the circle here. So you guys -- you addressed some of the elements around your strategy in the viewpoint of the market. How much more consolidation, do you think, is really needed to balance the
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then Tom, I'm not going to leave you out of the circle here. So you guys -- you addressed some of the elements around your strategy in the viewpoint of the market. How much more consolidation, do you think, is really needed to balance the market? In context -- or put that in context, vis-à-vis just natural attrition that's going to occur anyway. So will M&A accelerate attrition? Or is attrition already underway and will continue to underway irrespective of M&A? What's your perspective on that?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think we are in a transition period as far as the global fleet. And so we hit 2020, we hit that special 40 years from 1980 when so much of the fleet was built. And so we're -- it's sort of when -- I think when people look back 5, 10 years from now, they
componenttext: I think we are in a transition period as far as the global fleet. And so we hit 2020, we hit that special 40 years from 1980 when so much of the fleet was built. And so we're -- it's sort of when -- I think when people look back 5, 10 years from now, they'll say, "Well, that was the time the older fleets, the offshore drillers tend to build and have sort of quite intensive build cycles." And so we are going through a difficult period right now, which is sort of a necessary transition between old fleet in the '80s and the new fleet that is built in the sort of the 2005 to 2010 or -- and later. So I -- now having said that, there has been a -- there's a lot of assets out there. Some of them are going to go away, and we've seen that. And some of them will continue to go away. And our customers do -- have a strong track from new rigs. And in our marketing operations we've seen, when we're talking about opportunities, they normally are marketing and the customers requiring new rigs, and our customers will [ face ] anything. And more often than not, the answer is that they require new rigs. Now so as far as driving attrition, I don't think that M&A will necessarily drive attrition as far as make it -- people -- if the people got a rig that's basically going to create value and it will lead those value in these assets, I don't think M&A necessarily does that. What creates attrition is customers no longer wanting particular assets. Having said that, we have -- historically, we have some. So it's a little hard to say. But I think it's really about how good the asset is. And does it fit in the global fleets or even in a particular driller's fleet. I know from Rowan's perspective, we've been very careful about when we screen selling rigs to either scrap them or sell them into motor mode. We've done for almost all of us. So I don't think M&A necessarily drives attrition. Certainly, it doesn't detract from it, though.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: Okay. I appreciate it. And I guess a follow-up for Mark. For the significant deepwater contracts won this year, we can see the one that work. We often can't see the day rate. We certainly can't see the other terms and conditions. So I was hoping to get your thoughts on how those other terms and conditions have been trending. Whether those seemed to have bottomed earlier this year? Or whether there are still pressure for contractors to take more risks?

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Right now, David, what we're seeing in the market, and we've actually backed away from a couple of deals because of risk allocation in contracts, we're still seeing some very onerous contract terms with some of the contracts. And we have pushed back. And
componenttext: Right now, David, what we're seeing in the market, and we've actually backed away from a couple of deals because of risk allocation in contracts, we're still seeing some very onerous contract terms with some of the contracts. And we have pushed back. And it has probably hurt us in a couple of situations on some ultra-deepwater bids, but we're just willing to bet the company on a 2- or 3-year contract. And we just thought it'd make a lot of sense to lock the rigs up for multiple years at low day rates and taking a lot of risk. We're just not going to do that.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add to that, David. This is Tom. I'd just add to that. We don't know the contract terms other drillers have taken, so it is a little anecdotal. And customers, obviously, in a down cycle, we expect them to encourage a change in the risk alloc
componenttext: And I'll just add to that, David. This is Tom. I'd just add to that. We don't know the contract terms other drillers have taken, so it is a little anecdotal. And customers, obviously, in a down cycle, we expect them to encourage a change in the risk allocation. So we don't know. But we certainly -- the contract environment, it is becoming the coming tougher. And I think all of us are evaluating our traditional stand on risk allocation. I'd say that we are probably one of the more conservative companies. And though we're not the only one, I think I remember other drillers out there that view the world as [indiscernible], although we really don't know. I would say that there's, obviously -- as you mentioned, there's the price and then there's how many price options are there at the time. There's a lot of elements. And also the duration is one of the elements. So it's something that's so dynamic on the Rowan side, and we continue to evaluate it.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eduardo Royes from Jefferies.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up, actually, on that sort of question. And so I'm curious. If you can get contract terms that are less onerous, right, if you assume that it's something you're totally comfortable with, you've seen some guys there, obviously, come out
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up, actually, on that sort of question. And so I'm curious. If you can get contract terms that are less onerous, right, if you assume that it's something you're totally comfortable with, you've seen some guys there, obviously, come out and bring things for short-term jobs. As you're sitting there with the 3 -- with 3 idle drillships, is there a willingness, at least early on because you don't want this thing to sit idle longer term, maybe bring at least the first one out for a short-term job. I guess, I'm just trying to think. You hear some of your peers starting to talk about portfolio approach to this. Obviously, you don't want to lock in everything at low rates. Just a little bit more color on if, in fact, we continue to see the favorable trends we saw in the third quarter with more contracts, including more long term. So now you can effectively maybe pick, right, short-term and long-term jobs, how you'll approach that. Again, assuming that these are contracts that you're willing -- that the risk is fine there.

headline: Rowan Companies plc, Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'd say that's a good question, Eduardo. We do sort of think of it from a little bit of a portfolio perspective, although our portfolio is -- the number of drillships that we have is a lot smaller than some of our competitors. So if you have 15 drillships
componenttext: I'd say that's a good question, Eduardo. We do sort of think of it from a little bit of a portfolio perspective, although our portfolio is -- the number of drillships that we have is a lot smaller than some of our competitors. So if you have 15 drillships, you're willing to put some. And then you can get the upside later on with the others. When you only have 4 and 1 one is working, you definitely have to be. But we do consider it in that portfolio. Certainly, the value creative in the first one, we put back to work of the 3 versus the third. We do think about that -- we do believe that will be different. I'd say on short-term jobs, we actually like the idea of short-term jobs, but we always are sort of cognizant of what is on the back of them. Is there an opportunity? So what we don't want to do is ramp up a drillship with all the crews, hire a number of people on the lower levels. We have enough on the senior levels already. Get the rig back to work. Ramp it up. Get everybody fully competent through a very short job and then have to lay everybody off. That is not -- there's a number of reasons not to doing that. It is because, first of all, that's probably -- it will destroy more value from keeping them stacked. And also, we want to -- we're looking for a bit more opportunity than that. Having said that, will we take short-term jobs? And do we believe a hot rig is more marketable than a one-stack rig? Absolutely. And so we evaluated off each opportunity. And frankly, a lot of the shorter-term jobs, they're actually pretty attractive. As long as we think there's something on the back end which, frankly, today versus 6 months ago, there are more opportunities on the back end. So I think for us and for the other drillers, short-term jobs are actually pretty interesting because we feel like the market is going to improve. And therefore, you'd be sort of in an even better -- you'd have some of the best -- you would have some of the best rigs in the world. And they would be hot as opposed to one-stacked.

componenttext: Yes, yes. That's very -- that's helpful. I guess just my -- a quick follow up, probably for Stephen. componenttext: Sure, Eduardo. It is a slight reduction in our SPS schedule next year versus this year and versus 2019. But also keep in mind, our fleet, it has also shrunk to a degree. We've retired some rigs. And we've also now contributed these 3 rigs to ARO, and we'll be contributing 2 more next year. So I think our run rate going forward is going to be lower. And I think that, of course, it is impacted slightly by the lower asset we have on schedule next year.
